headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Deere's First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Ms. Marie Ziegler, Vice President, Investor Relations.
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Deere's First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Ms. Marie Ziegler, Vice President, Investor Relations.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Also on today's call are Jim Field, our Chief Financial Officer; and Susan Karlix and Justin Merrimac from the Deere Investor Relations staff. Today, we'll take a closer look at Deere's first quarter earnings and then spend some time talking
componenttext: Good morning. Also on today's call are Jim Field, our Chief Financial Officer; and Susan Karlix and Justin Merrimac from the Deere Investor Relations staff. Today, we'll take a closer look at Deere's first quarter earnings and then spend some time talking about our markets and provide you an update on how we see 2010 is shaping up. After that, we will open for questions. Please note that slides are available to complement the call this morning. They can be accessed on our website at www.johndeere.com. First as usual, a reminder. This call is being broadcast live on the Internet and recorded for future transmission and use by Deere and Thomson Reuters. Any other use, recording, or transmission of any portion of this copyrighted broadcast without the expressed written consent of Deere is strictly prohibited. Participants in the call, including the Q&A section, agree that their license and remarks and all media, may be stored and used as part of the earnings call.Today's call includes forward-looking comments concerning the company's projections, plans and objectives for the future that are subject to important risks and uncertainties. Actual results might differ materially from those projected in these forward-looking statements. Additional information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ materially is contained in the company's most recent Form 8-K and periodic reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company, except as required by law, undertakes no obligation to update or revise these forward-looking information. The call and the company material are not an offer to sell or a solicitation of offers to buy any of the company's security.This call also may include financial measures that are not in conformance with accounting principles, generally accepted in the United States of America, otherwise known as GAAP. Additional information concerning these measures, including reconciliations to comparable GAAP measures is posted on our website at www.johndeere.com/financialreports, under Other Financial Information. Call participants should consider the other information on risks and uncertainties and non-GAAP measures, in addition to the information presented on the call. And now for a closer look at our first quarter, here's Susan.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Marie. This morning, John Deere reported results for the first quarter of 2010, and what a quarter it was. In spite of a decline in sales, earnings were up 19% from a year ago. The improvement was led by our Ag & Turf and Credit businesses, bot
componenttext: Thank you, Marie. This morning, John Deere reported results for the first quarter of 2010, and what a quarter it was. In spite of a decline in sales, earnings were up 19% from a year ago. The improvement was led by our Ag & Turf and Credit businesses, both of which are experiencing improved conditions. Disciplined costs and asset management were again major stories, with SA&G expense, a little changed and trade receivables and inventories, down by $1.4 billion. Finally, our full-year forecast for earnings has been increased significantly to $1.3 billion. All in all, it was an impressive performance. Now let's look at the quarter in more detail starting with Slide 3.First quarter net income attributable to Deere & Company was $243 million or $0.57 per share on net sales and revenues of $4.8 billion. It was the second highest earnings total for any first quarter in the company's history, trailing only the first quarter of 2008. As shown on Slide 4, total worldwide Equipment Operations net sales were down 7% in the first quarter versus first quarter of 2009. Currency translation on net sales was positive by about five points, with about two points of positive price realization.Turning to Slide 5, worldwide production tonnage was down 20% in the quarter. However, demand has been better than expected for large Ag and international Forestry product, accounting for the improvement in our tonnage forecast. For the full year, projected production tonnage is now forecast to be up about 5%. Let's turn to the company outlook on Slide 6. Second quarter sales are expected to be up 4% to 6% compared with the second quarter of 2009. Currency translation is expected to be positive by about five points, with about two points of positive price realization. For the full year, net equipment sales are forecast to be up 6% to 8% compared with fiscal year 2009. This includes about three points of positive currency translation and one to two points of positive price realization. Net income attributable to Deere & Company is now forecast to be about $1.3 billion for the year.Turning to a review of our individual businesses, let's start with Agriculture & Turf on Slide 7. In the quarter, net sales were down 6%, with production tonnage down 20%. Operating profit was $352 million in the quarter. Lower raw material costs, positive price realizations and the favorable effects of foreign currency translation and product mix, offset lower sales volumes and higher post-retirement benefit costs. A&T is starting to see benefits from last year's organizational realignment, resulting in the creation of the Ag & Turf division. Ongoing rationalization of processes, facilities and resources is allowing the division to more efficiently meet customer needs and reduce overall costs.Before we review the sales outlook, let's look at some of the fundamentals affecting the Ag business starting on Slide 8. Commodity prices for the '09, '10 crop have risen modestly since our last forecast. Corn acreage is expected to increase 1.5 million acres in 2010 to meet growing demand for feed, export and ethanol. What's more? Corn is expected to be more profitable this year. According to Informa, profits from corn will be $77 an acre more than soybeans in 2010. This is an additional $15 an acre above the 2009 levels.For soybeans, continued robust export demand will keep prices relatively high in the near term. Finally, cotton prices remain well above the year ago level, driven by lower production in Asia and the rapidly recovering Asian economy. Turning to Slide 9, forecast prices as you can see are below the very high levels of 2008, but remain strong on a historical basis. On Slide 10, 2010 U.S. farm cash receipts are now forecast to be up about 4% from 2009 levels. The biggest changes in the Livestock sector were milk prices have continued to climb and things are generally headed in the right direction.Slide 11 highlights farm net income in Brazil and Argentina. Argentina is recovering from the 2009 drought, driving increased demand for tractors, combines, sprayers and storage equipment. In Brazil, 2010 farm net income is expected to double from last year's level. Normally, when we talk about Brazil, we talk about soybeans. However, the primary driver if increased farm net income in 2010 is the large improvement in sugar. International sugar prices are extremely strong. Demand is higher than production due to a drastic drought-driven reduction in sugar output from India and China. Strong demand for sugar is only part of the story in Brazil. Other positive factors include demand for Brazilian commodities globally, as well as government sponsored low rate finance programs like FINAME and Mais Alimentos. These are all contributing to positive producer attitudes, which translate into higher spending on farm equipment.Putting all that together, as you can see on Slide 12, our outlook for industry sales of agricultural equipment in the U.S. and Canada is comparable to 2009. This is up significantly from our previous forecast of down about 10%. The strength we've seen in our order book is driving this increase. For example, the combine early order program ended in January with a significantly higher than expected response rate. Demand for large tractors has been higher than expected as well. On the 8R Series Tractor, we have added schedule as orders have come in, effective availability in September 2010. The story is same on the 9000 Series Tractors, with effective availability in May 2010. Conditions in Western Europe are weak, with Ag sales there expected to be down 10% to 15% in the year. Farmer sentiment is low and used equipment inventories remain high due to the lack of products going to Central Europe. We expect sales in Central Europe and the CIS to remain under pressure as well. Things look better in South America, where sales are projected to increase 10% to 15%.  Turning to another product category, we expect retail sales of Turf equipment and compact utility tractors in the U.S. and Canada to be flat for the year, after a sharp drop in 2009.On Slide 13, Deere sales for worldwide Ag & Turf are projected to be up 4% to 6% in the year versus our previous forecast of down about 4%. Currency translation is projected to be positive about four points. As just discussed, demand for large Ag equipment is much stronger than anticipated. Product mix has shifted in our favor as well. In November, we talked about product mix, referring to sales of different categories of equipment being a factor in our lower 2010 outlook. At the time, we expected sales of large Ag products to be down almost 10%, with the large absorption of these products negatively affecting operating margins. In our current forecast, the anticipated improvement in large Ag will change the mix. We now expect mix to be neutral in 2010.The division will benefit from operating improvements made in 2009, as well as from positive price realization, lower material costs and the positive effects of currency. Conversely, about $300 million of the increase in pension OPEB expense will be charged to Ag & Turf. Also, the division will see higher R&D expense, primarily for Interim Tier 4, the Regulatory Engine Emission Standards in the U.S. and Stage III B in Europe.In Turf, we are encouraged by strong retail demand in commercial mowing and golf and turf equipment in January. For the year, the A&T division's operating margin is forecast to be around 10%. Let's focus now on Construction & Forestry on Slide 14.With continuing weak markets in the U.S. and abroad, net sales were down 15% in the quarter. Production tonnage was down 22%. The division reported an operating loss of $37 million. Again this quarter, C&F demonstrated commitment to its trough management plan through tight expense control but higher pension and OPEB expense, as well as higher R&D expense, mainly associated with Interim Tier 4 spending resulted in a decremental margin of about 50%. Without these two items, C&F's decremental margin would have been in the mid-20s. Through the aggressive management of production level, the division has continued to successfully manage inventories. At the end of January, based on inventory levels reported to the Association of Equipment Manufacturers, Deere Construction dealers in the U.S. and Canada were carrying about 1/3 less the inventory than the rest of the industry based on percent of days on hand.On Slide 15, Construction & Forestry sales are now expected to be up about 21% in 2010, up from the very low levels of 2009 and from our previous forecast of up about 18%. On the Construction side as you see from the chart, U.S. economic indicators for 2010 indicate the retail market will remain weak. Non-residential spending is forecast to be down again in 2010 due to ripple effects from the depressed housing sector coupled with tight credit conditions. Overall, we believe the retail market for Construction Equipment will be down 5% to 10% in 2010. Things are looking a little better however, for global forestry markets. Improving global economic conditions, better pulp prices and low-field inventories will benefit the Forestry segment in 2010. Again, this is in comparison with the very low levels of 2009. Deere's C&F division will benefit from higher production and sales. However, these will be offset by a higher charge of about $100 million for pension and OPEB expense. Other headwinds include higher R&D expenses, primarily for Interim Tier 4, as well as a possible material cost increase and roughly flat pricing. As a result, the C&F division's operating margins are expected to be similar to 2009.Let's move now to our credit operations. Slide 16 shows the worldwide credit operations provision for credit losses as a percent of the total average portfolio. In the first quarter, the provision on an annualized basis ran 52 basis points. Write-offs in the Construction & Forestry portfolios were lower than expected and lower than a year ago in absolute dollars. While this is encouraging, we aren't prepared to say we've turned the corner. The full-year provision is still forecast to run around 89 basis points, roughly the same as last year.On Slide 17, past dues for the worldwide Credit operation are about flat with last year. Annualized write-offs continue to reflect the excellent performance of our Ag portfolio. The Construction & Forestry rate has increased, but as noted a few moments ago, write-offs in dollars are lower than a year ago. The percentage is higher because the portfolio, the denominator, is lower. This reflects the steep decline in U.S. Construction Equipment sales since 2006.Moving to Slide 18, worldwide Credit operations net income attributable to Deere & Company was $81 million in the quarter versus $45 million last year. The biggest factor was an improvement in financing spreads. This resulted from interest rates returning to more historical spreads following the interest rate volatility in late 2008 and early 2009. Looking ahead, we are projecting worldwide Credit operations net income attributable to Deere & Company of about $260 million in 2010.Now let's turn our focus back to the equipment operations and take a look at receivables and inventory on Slide 19. For the company as a whole, receivables and inventories were down roughly $1.4 billion in the quarter. Since our last outlook, in light of the higher than anticipated production levels expected in the fourth quarter, we are forecasting receivables and inventory to be up about $450 million in 2010. Now let's discuss the latest on retail sales.Slide 20 presents the product category details for the month of January expressed in units. Utility tractor industry sales were down 7%. Deere was down less than the industry. Row-crop tractor industry sales were up 32%, Deere was up more than the industry. Four-wheel-drive tractor industry sales were up 5%. Deere was up a single-digit but more than the industry. Combine industry sales were up 14%. Deere was up more than the industry. Looking at Deere dealer inventories in the bottom chart for row-crop tractors, Deere ended January with inventories at 21% of trailing 12 month sales. Combine inventories were at 6% of sales. As January percentage trailing 12 months retail sales have seen a slight uptick for row crop tractors year-over-year. At the end of January, the absolute number of units in inventory for both row-crop tractors and combines, as a percent of trailing 12 month sales, was lower than a year ago.Turning to Slide 21. In Western Europe, sales of John Deere tractors were down double digits and combines were up double digits in January. Deere's retail sales of selected Turf and utility equipment in the U.S. and Canada were up a single-digit in the month. Construction & Forestry sales in the U.S. and Canada on both first-in-the-dirt and settlement basis were down double digits for the month.Slide 22 shows raw material and logistics costs down about $160 million in the quarter. We now forecast material cost decreases of approximately $150 million for the year. This is slightly lower than our previous forecast, reflecting higher commodity price projections for inputs like steel. This estimate could deteriorate further if commodity prices rise more than anticipated and the dollar weakens from its present level. The Ag & Turf division savings is forecasted at about $150 million. For Construction & Forestry, due to the currency impact on partner products, we are now forecasting C&F material costs to be flat to up $25 million.Looking at R&D expense on Slide 23, R&D was up about 7% in the first quarter, with currency translation accounting for about two points. R&D expense is expected to be up about 12% in fiscal 2010 with currency accounting for about one point. The bulk of the increase is accounted for by Interim Tier 4 emission spending.Moving now to Slide 24, pension expense in the first quarter was about $110 million. As discussed last quarter, the 2010 forecast calls for an increase of about $400 million in pension and OPEB expense, primarily due to a change in the discount rate. Of the $400 million change, about $325 million will hit cost of sales, leading about $75 million in SA&G. Ag & Turf has responsibility for about $300 million of the additional expense while the increase for C&F is about $100 million.On Slide 25, equipment operations SA&G expense was up about 1% in the quarter. Currency translation accounted for about four points. Pension and OPEB added about three points. Excluding these two items, SA&G expense would've been down about six points in the quarter. For fiscal 2010, we now project SA&G to be up about eight points. Pension and OPEB accounts for about three points. Variable incentive compensation contributes about three points of the change and currency about two points.Moving to the tax rate on Slide 26. The implied first quarter tax rate for the equipment operations was about 36%. For 2010, the full-year effective tax rate is expected to be in the range of 34% to 35%. Before touching on cash flow, currency movements, both translation and transactions or trade flows increased operating profit by about $75 million in the first quarter.On Slide 27, you see the strong cash flow from our equipment operations even in years of tough market conditions. This reflects in large part, our success managing assets and controlling working capital levels. We anticipate strong cash flow from the equipment operations in 2010, $1.9 billion, up from last year's $1.4 billion. Such strong cash flow is further testament to the execution and success of the SVA model.On Slide 28, capital expenditures are now expected to be about $900 million, primarily driven by Interim Tier 4. Depreciation and amortization is projected to be about $600 million. Our forecast currently includes about $600 million of pension and OPEB contributions in the year and capital spending for financial services is forecasted around $200 million in 2010, primarily for wind projects. In closing, John Deere has started 2010 on a strongly positive note and is looking for further improvement in the year ahead. Our performance in the face of stubbornly weak global economic conditions reflects the solid execution of our operating and marketing plans, and our success in taking costs and asset discipline to a new level. We remained squarely focused on our customers as well, expanding our global customer base and extending our competitive position. As a result of these factors, we continue to believe that our company is well prepared to capitalize on an eventual upturn in the economy and well-positioned to meet the world's growing need for food, fuel, shelter and infrastructure in the years to come.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010

componenttext: Thank you, Susan. We are now ready to begin the Q&A session of the call and Laura, our operator will instruct us on the pooling procedure. But as a reminder, and I do very firmly remind you that we're asking for you no more than two questions and a multi-part question does count as multiple questions. With that, Laura?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Jamie Cook [Credit Suisse].
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Jamie Cook [Credit Suisse].

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Marie, can you give any more color in the first quarter how much, can you quantify what the material cost benefit was in the first quarter when we think about the Ag margins and just how that plays out throughout the year because I'm perplexed by your fla
componenttext: Marie, can you give any more color in the first quarter how much, can you quantify what the material cost benefit was in the first quarter when we think about the Ag margins and just how that plays out throughout the year because I'm perplexed by your flat margin comment for Ag for the full year? And then the other question would just be, just a little more color on what you're seeing on Western European trends within farm. You didn't change your top line forecast but sort of how you're thinking about your inventory levels and production relative to the industry and any color you can give by country?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Why don't we start with Western Europe first. Farmer moved there continues to be pretty somber. And as a result, you'll note that we have not changed our guidance, which is the industry will be down 10% to 15%. We do see some differences in some countries
componenttext: Why don't we start with Western Europe first. Farmer moved there continues to be pretty somber. And as a result, you'll note that we have not changed our guidance, which is the industry will be down 10% to 15%. We do see some differences in some countries because of the currency relationships. You do see some a little bit more strengthened in places like the U.K. and Poland because their currencies are -- the farm on these [ph] are paid in euros and the currencies are relatively stronger. But generally speaking, livestock is maybe stabilizing, some that stabilizing at pretty low levels and you continue to see a backup of used equipment. But we've cited this a couple of times in the calls before, it's not yet at worrisome levels but it does act as the cautionary note in the market. Moving on to margins, our raw material guidance is $150 million for the year and basically, we got it all in the first quarter and generally speaking, flat through the rest of the year. You'll note too that when we talk about things like R&D and SA&G, we're relatively light in the first quarter. Those costs will increase at least as what forecast has been doing as you move through the year, and of course Ag, is the bigger piece to both of those numbers.

And I guess I'm sort of surprise that it's going to lose money for the year and that's now how [ph] you expect money in any of the quarters, given the scenario? What's going on is it all because of the Interim Tier 4 investment or what's going on that you -- but I [ph] think of any sort of operational improvement?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: There are really factors, even though their sales are up, basically that incremental margin is absorbed by about $100 million pension and OPEB increase, which we had talked about last quarter's net still in play. They too have higher R&D and is actually f
componenttext: There are really factors, even though their sales are up, basically that incremental margin is absorbed by about $100 million pension and OPEB increase, which we had talked about last quarter's net still in play. They too have higher R&D and is actually for the divisions of the full year it's about $40 million. So it's not insignificant. And they have just one other factor -- material cost we have a headwind of flat to up about $25 million. So the mid a point of that would be, what? 10 to 15.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And that's just wiping out all of the profitability?
componenttext: And that's just wiping out all of the profitability?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010

componenttext: Basically that absorbs it all.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010

componenttext: You have increased Ag production significantly. And I think if you reference at the fourth quarter, it's going to be much higher. Can you give us an insight to have the Ag sales a look for the rest of the year? Second quarter obviously, probably still be the strongest of the year, but in a much stronger fourth quarter now that you said it before, that was indicated?

componenttext: That really was referencing than what we anticipated. But basically versus a year ago because a year ago we were we had significant side downs. So this year, we will be in production at a higher level and that of course goes on to affect our trade receivables.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Robert Wertheimer [Morgan Stanley].
componenttext: Our next question comes from Robert Wertheimer [Morgan Stanley].

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I have two questions on production schedule. The first is just how you think about it, we've been hearing and we believe underlying demand is fairly strong. Have you raise the combine production and is that done, are you pretty much going to produce what
componenttext: I have two questions on production schedule. The first is just how you think about it, we've been hearing and we believe underlying demand is fairly strong. Have you raise the combine production and is that done, are you pretty much going to produce what you're going to produce? and similar on the large tractor side, would you potentially if demand continues to be strong, pump that up again or are you aiming to hit a certain schedule?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've certainly would do anything that we could to meet our customers demand requirements. And to go back to one of your earlier point, yes, we have a pretty significantly increased our projected production for our combines and actually for large tractors
componenttext: We've certainly would do anything that we could to meet our customers demand requirements. And to go back to one of your earlier point, yes, we have a pretty significantly increased our projected production for our combines and actually for large tractors. And that, as we talk about that, is really the single biggest factor driving the change in the top line and income guidance.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've heard a couple of farmers, not a lot but a couple talking about nervousness about the Tier 4 engine, not so much of the price, but wanting somebody else to take the risk on the first year of the engine. And so are you concerned about the pre-buy, do
componenttext: We've heard a couple of farmers, not a lot but a couple talking about nervousness about the Tier 4 engine, not so much of the price, but wanting somebody else to take the risk on the first year of the engine. And so are you concerned about the pre-buy, does that affect your production decision for this year and what's your strategy for showing farmers that the engine [ph] is going to work how you're going to roll that out?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've already been at farm shows, starting to introduce the product. We're starting to get news on magazine articles, talking about the production. I would like at anytime you have a major change in the machine there's always some customers who want the f
componenttext: We've already been at farm shows, starting to introduce the product. We're starting to get news on magazine articles, talking about the production. I would like at anytime you have a major change in the machine there's always some customers who want the first in technology. There would be some interesting product benefits and some of the products that comes along with it and there is a tremendous need to continue to improve productivity. We, over the long-term, need to increase food for the world. And so I would say that this is something that we manage through before. We will be doing -- we have a very significant rollout plan in terms of training, and education to our dealers and technicians and of course for customers, who have plenty of opportunities.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Marie, the hit on this training -- and this is a huge undertaking, we've got 20 different courses. we're rolling out in 14 different languages. We've already touched more than 8,000 dealer personnel. And so all that is really about educating the folks tha
componenttext: Marie, the hit on this training -- and this is a huge undertaking, we've got 20 different courses. we're rolling out in 14 different languages. We've already touched more than 8,000 dealer personnel. And so all that is really about educating the folks that are at the front-line interaction with the customers to help the customers get the level of confidence that they need, and to make sure that we can deliver the John Deere experience. So it's a huge undertaking.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ann Duignan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ann Duignan.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: JPMorgan. Marie, it's kind of a double-edged sword that -- whomever wants to address this -- that currency is positively impacting your outlook for equipment sales. However, the double-edged sword is a stronger dollar could impact both your equipment expo
componenttext: JPMorgan. Marie, it's kind of a double-edged sword that -- whomever wants to address this -- that currency is positively impacting your outlook for equipment sales. However, the double-edged sword is a stronger dollar could impact both your equipment exports, as well as soft commodity exports. Can you talk a little bit about what exactly is in your outlook for currency, particularly euro-dollar exchange rate and what's the upside versus the downside risk that you see with that forecast?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Specifically, we do have a practice of not forecasting what the currency will do. And so we look at the rate that we have experienced in the quarter and use that to forecast, going forward. And that would've been a euro that was 1 40 or -- 1 46 was the av
componenttext: Specifically, we do have a practice of not forecasting what the currency will do. And so we look at the rate that we have experienced in the quarter and use that to forecast, going forward. And that would've been a euro that was 1 40 or -- 1 46 was the average.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: 1 46 was the average rate for the quarter, and that's what we used, going forward.
componenttext: 1 46 was the average rate for the quarter, and that's what we used, going forward.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: For the company, in terms of Europe, specifically, the primary tractor in Europe is the mid-size tractor and those are manufactured in Europe. That's the primary source for this. So we do a fairly good job of trying to match production to where the market
componenttext: For the company, in terms of Europe, specifically, the primary tractor in Europe is the mid-size tractor and those are manufactured in Europe. That's the primary source for this. So we do a fairly good job of trying to match production to where the markets are.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: You did benefit last cycle though from significant exports of combines out of North America into places like Eastern Europe.
componenttext: You did benefit last cycle though from significant exports of combines out of North America into places like Eastern Europe.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Eastern Europe and Russia, that's a whole different set of circumstances. Go ahead, Jim.
componenttext: Well, Eastern Europe and Russia, that's a whole different set of circumstances. Go ahead, Jim.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And a lot of those transactions will be denominated in dollars as well.
componenttext: And a lot of those transactions will be denominated in dollars as well.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Ann, you're aware that the single biggest factor in our outlook there is the circumstances in Russia. And we're working to get up an assembly facility up and running. We're on time for that, we said in the spring, and we're working with the Russian go
componenttext: And Ann, you're aware that the single biggest factor in our outlook there is the circumstances in Russia. And we're working to get up an assembly facility up and running. We're on time for that, we said in the spring, and we're working with the Russian government to make sure we all understand the terms. So we're on track there, too.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then my follow-up question is a similar question but on interest rates. Interest rates have helped support very aggressive pricing out there in the marketplace not just from John Deere, but from competitors at large. And it has been a positive for you
componenttext: And then my follow-up question is a similar question but on interest rates. Interest rates have helped support very aggressive pricing out there in the marketplace not just from John Deere, but from competitors at large. And it has been a positive for your Financial Services business. Can you talk a little bit about your outlook for interest rates, going forward, and how that might impact your Financial Services business?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: We -- I don't think really have been out front with a explicit forecast. But our financial services business is all about -- we don't really take positions on rates so much. We try to lock in finance for it, and be a match-funded such that these swings, u
componenttext: We -- I don't think really have been out front with a explicit forecast. But our financial services business is all about -- we don't really take positions on rates so much. We try to lock in finance for it, and be a match-funded such that these swings, unless they happen very quickly and/or very violently, that they don't impact the earnings stream too much. Having said that, in general, our view would be for a increasing rate environment over the course of the year. And that would be a very, very modest view, though. And we have factored that into some of our forecast on the financial services side, but also on the equipment side because that generally results in higher interest waiver charges.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Henry Kirn [ph].
componenttext: Our next question comes from Henry Kirn [ph].

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't cite it so much as a pre-buy because we know that the primary drivers of customer demand are good levels of cash receipts to the farm income. And you certainly would agree, going back to Ann's comments, lower interest rates certainly have also
componenttext: I wouldn't cite it so much as a pre-buy because we know that the primary drivers of customer demand are good levels of cash receipts to the farm income. And you certainly would agree, going back to Ann's comments, lower interest rates certainly have also helped support that. You are aware that we had put additional capacity on both Harvester and at Waterloo last year and actually at many, many of our factories globally. So we have the ability to respond to additional demand. That said, for our combine program in the U.S. and Canada, round numbers, 95% of our orders are already in place and we adjust production accordingly based on the results of our early-order program. So we could have some additional flexing there, but we're pretty well in position there.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, that is included in the benefits that we are citing because as we merged the two divisions together, there were people redundancies and processes that were improved really out of both sides of the business. We don't exist as two separate silos anymo
componenttext: Well, that is included in the benefits that we are citing because as we merged the two divisions together, there were people redundancies and processes that were improved really out of both sides of the business. We don't exist as two separate silos anymore. They're really fully-merged. And that's what generating for this year a $50 million to $60 million charge. I would just talk about the Landscapes business, too. They have very difficult market conditions because they are very focused on housing and driven by housing. And that business has unfortunately also had slight reductions, those who are at the bottom [ph], 800 people even to 1,000. And they've got closed emerged store locations, so they also are looking for some improvement in their financial results. And that is may be an additional $25 million this year. And then finally, you're aware that we closed our facility in Welland, and we're really in the final phases of that. And so there's some operating savings this year, assuming a pretax of about $40 million.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Steve Volkmann.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Steve Volkmann.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jefferies & Company. I'm just curious, what happened since your last forecast that you gave us that led to such better margin? I guess, it was all in the margin, but something must have really changed since the lens [ph] you were looking through in Novemb
componenttext: Jefferies & Company. I'm just curious, what happened since your last forecast that you gave us that led to such better margin? I guess, it was all in the margin, but something must have really changed since the lens [ph] you were looking through in November was kind of just so far off. How did the quarter evolve?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Really, in terms of the sales outlook for the year, the single biggest driver was that our order book developed pretty dramatically over the course of the first quarter and enabled us to improve our outlook for the industry from down then to basically fla
componenttext: Really, in terms of the sales outlook for the year, the single biggest driver was that our order book developed pretty dramatically over the course of the first quarter and enabled us to improve our outlook for the industry from down then to basically flat. So that's the single biggest driver.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And at a much different level than that, because that's a single biggest driver, but we also experienced a more favorable currency than we would've built into those original estimates.
componenttext: And at a much different level than that, because that's a single biggest driver, but we also experienced a more favorable currency than we would've built into those original estimates.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: In the quarter. I was about to remind everyone, that was about a $75 million translation in transaction benefit in the first quarter.
componenttext: In the quarter. I was about to remind everyone, that was about a $75 million translation in transaction benefit in the first quarter.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe this is for Jim but whoever wants to take it. We've talked a little bit about how you have a lot of liquidity on the balance sheet. You're obviously continuing to generate a lot of cash. At some point, some of that cash, I guess, becomes available f
componenttext: Maybe this is for Jim but whoever wants to take it. We've talked a little bit about how you have a lot of liquidity on the balance sheet. You're obviously continuing to generate a lot of cash. At some point, some of that cash, I guess, becomes available for things like share repurchases or dividends or even acquisitions. But I think you've said that you wanted to kind of wait and see how things evolve in the financial markets. Has there been any evolution over the last few months?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say, first of all, you're right on. That's what we said. And I would say we have this well-articulated use-of-cash policy and one of the uses of cash that we talked about also is making sure that our pension plans are fully-funded. And so we did i
componenttext: I would say, first of all, you're right on. That's what we said. And I would say we have this well-articulated use-of-cash policy and one of the uses of cash that we talked about also is making sure that our pension plans are fully-funded. And so we did increase funding to the pension plans by about $250 million in terms of the forecast. In terms of how we view the world, I think we still think we're on a relatively fragile foundation. In the fourth quarter '09, we are all shocked by the whole home device situation and what the implications of that may have been for the capital markets. And then, of course, then we move into the first quarter, and we get the Eurozone issue. Having said that, we are targeting -- we had about 12-month target of pre-funding at the end of '09, and we will be coming off that moving more into the six- to nine-month range by '10, by the end of this year.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Alex Blanton.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Alex Blanton.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ingalls & Snyder. Marie, in the last conference call in November, you talked about the construction, forestry seeming to be up 18%, and factory sales with the retail sales, down 5% to 10%. And you basically made the same forecast this time, except saying
componenttext: Ingalls & Snyder. Marie, in the last conference call in November, you talked about the construction, forestry seeming to be up 18%, and factory sales with the retail sales, down 5% to 10%. And you basically made the same forecast this time, except saying that the factory sales would be up 21% and the retail sales, again, down 5% to 10%. So if that is primarily due to a lower inventory reduction year-over-year, maybe a flat inventory versus a huge inventory reduction last year at the dealer level, now can we then take that concept and talk about the Ag business? What's happening at the dealer level in Ag inventory? And maybe you already mentioned this, but I didn't hear it, how much of the change in sales of Ag equipment might be due to less inventory reduction at the dealer level than last year?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: We aren't expecting any reduction in inventories in the Ag business at year-over-year and 30 of October [ph]. In fact, at the dealer level, we'll probably have at least our forecast has receivables and inventories up about $415 million. That's our guidanc
componenttext: We aren't expecting any reduction in inventories in the Ag business at year-over-year and 30 of October [ph]. In fact, at the dealer level, we'll probably have at least our forecast has receivables and inventories up about $415 million. That's our guidance at year end. And most of that will be in Ag receivables and it will simply be because we'll have a little bit more in the pipeline than we did a year ago.

componenttextpreview: ISI [International Strategy and Investment Group]. My question relates to your Ag & Turf outlook. What you reported in the first quarter and what you're seeing for the full year implies the next three quarters, the rest of the year, your Ag & Turf sales a
componenttext: ISI [International Strategy and Investment Group]. My question relates to your Ag & Turf outlook. What you reported in the first quarter and what you're seeing for the full year implies the next three quarters, the rest of the year, your Ag & Turf sales are up nearly 8%, but your operating profit margins are down about 60 bps year-over-year. And it looks like from what you're implying about costs, generally neutral the rest of the year on a year-over-year basis, pricing, up, for the whole company up about $200 million, rest of year -- I have to assume a lot of that's Ag, not construction.

componenttextpreview: That's fair.

componenttext: The increase in R&D, which was up 7%. In the first quarter, it's up 12%. Higher SA&G, which was basically, I think, was up like 1% in the quarter. And our guidance has it up for the full year, SA&G for the year, up 8%. So basically that's all back-end loaded.

componenttext: Remember, the Ag division will eat about $300 million more of pension. componenttext: True, but at the end of day, for the rest of the year, sales are implied up 7.8% for Ag & Turf. Volume margins are at 10.1%, and you did 10.7% the last three quarters of last year.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: That would be a factor, but that's really in the SA&G and I believe there's some of it in cost of sales as well. But the other thing is that it's somewhat of a timing. Our SA&G came in last year, a little more uniformly than what we are currently projecti
componenttext: That would be a factor, but that's really in the SA&G and I believe there's some of it in cost of sales as well. But the other thing is that it's somewhat of a timing. Our SA&G came in last year, a little more uniformly than what we are currently projecting this year. Again, we had almost flat in the first quarter, and yet you're looking for a gain in over the course of the year. So you're going to have a bigger increase year-over-year in quarters two through four.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Buckingham Research. I just wondered if you can spend a minute to break apart the Construction & Forestry and talk about the different trends in those different end markets?
componenttext: Buckingham Research. I just wondered if you can spend a minute to break apart the Construction & Forestry and talk about the different trends in those different end markets?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, Forestry accounts for the improvement in the Construction & Forestry outlook. We originally had said our sales would be up 18 [ph] and up 21 and really it's because we are starting to see a better ordering activity. Principally, it's coming out
componenttext: Actually, Forestry accounts for the improvement in the Construction & Forestry outlook. We originally had said our sales would be up 18 [ph] and up 21 and really it's because we are starting to see a better ordering activity. Principally, it's coming out of Europe. But now we're talking about extremely low levels, really, in forestry across the globe last year. Just trying to see a little bit of improvement. On the construction side, there was actually no change from our previous forecast. So all the incremental change occurred on the forestry side.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then the source of the strength in the farmer purchasing, is that all pre-buy related or is there something --
componenttext: And then the source of the strength in the farmer purchasing, is that all pre-buy related or is there something --

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and dually, customers -- I've actually looked though the comments, they're talking about good farm income. They're talking about the need to maintain their normal trading cycles. We hypothesized, in fact, that maybe some of the very difficult conditi
componenttext: Yes, and dually, customers -- I've actually looked though the comments, they're talking about good farm income. They're talking about the need to maintain their normal trading cycles. We hypothesized, in fact, that maybe some of the very difficult conditions, planting in the last few springs and then of course what happened this fall with the very late harvest, may also be supporting that. We also know that interest, low interest rates are very supportive to farmers purchasing position.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010

componenttext: Well, engine compliance date [ph] start in January of 2011, and then there'll be a rolling product launches from there. But I don't have any specific announcements on when we'll be talking about products.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Marie, can you step us through what part of your cost structure was lower than you expected in the first quarter? I understand the point about increasing production in the balance of the year, but your production in the first quarter was mostly in lin
componenttext: And Marie, can you step us through what part of your cost structure was lower than you expected in the first quarter? I understand the point about increasing production in the balance of the year, but your production in the first quarter was mostly in line with what you were looking for and it looks like what margins were about call it 300 to 500 basis points higher than what you anticipated in your guidance was quarter. Was it higher plant efficiency levels? Credit gains from the Ag & Turf combination? Can you give us some more color on the drivers?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just to refresh your memory -- actually, we don't have guidance by quarter anymore. So you're probably looking at us compared to other modeling. But we would not have any comments about what we thought our income would be in the first quarter. That said,
componenttext: Just to refresh your memory -- actually, we don't have guidance by quarter anymore. So you're probably looking at us compared to other modeling. But we would not have any comments about what we thought our income would be in the first quarter. That said, if you look at it year-over-year, the mix, I think, which we were thinking would be a bit of a drag for us in the Ag operations. Actually, it was a positive in the quarter. We're telling for the full year, it's neutral. It actually was about a point's positive in the quarter in the margins, year-over-year. So that would've been an improvement. Material costs came in maybe a little stronger than expected. And then the currency which had not been in the forecast, that's about a seven about million Dollar operating benefit.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Seth Weber.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Seth Weber.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: RBC. Can you just talk about your confidence in the supply chain to meet your raised production outlook? And do you see any potential bottlenecks out there?
componenttext: RBC. Can you just talk about your confidence in the supply chain to meet your raised production outlook? And do you see any potential bottlenecks out there?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have worked for a long time very closely with our suppliers. And I think our execution in a difficult market, if you go all the way back to 2004, certainly as we were ramping up in late 2007, 2008, sort of speaks for itself. We do quarterly calls with
componenttext: We have worked for a long time very closely with our suppliers. And I think our execution in a difficult market, if you go all the way back to 2004, certainly as we were ramping up in late 2007, 2008, sort of speaks for itself. We do quarterly calls with our suppliers. Were working with them to make sure that if they have bottlenecks, we're working through them through those processes with them in the near term. We can maybe adjust some production to get things in early late, depending, to help accommodate their production. This time, and we just checked with our supply management folks again, we don't see any bottlenecks.

componenttext: No, our guidance is still that, that market is down in Western Europe 10% to 15% and there's nothing unfortunately on the first quarter that has shaken the outlook.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark Koznarek.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark Koznarek.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Cleveland Research. I have a question on the South American outlook, just using Brazil as a proxy for overall South America, which probably is part of the answer to the question, but it looks like unit shipments for the first three months of your fiscal y
componenttext: Cleveland Research. I have a question on the South American outlook, just using Brazil as a proxy for overall South America, which probably is part of the answer to the question, but it looks like unit shipments for the first three months of your fiscal year are up 35% for tractors and 70% for combines and the implication of even the top end of the guidance, 15% for the market for the year actually means combines would have to be down for the final nine months of the year and tractors would be up kind of a high single-digit. So should we think about your South American outlook being conservative? Or is there something in the latter part of the year that you're expecting?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess, two things. One is that South American look is influenced by conditions in other markets. And although we see Argentina coming back, it's coming back some pretty low levels and then you have various sorted circumstances in other markets, so
componenttext: Well, I guess, two things. One is that South American look is influenced by conditions in other markets. And although we see Argentina coming back, it's coming back some pretty low levels and then you have various sorted circumstances in other markets, so that's one factor. The other thing is that FINAME, that current program end at the end of June. Our forecast anticipates that they will be renewed but probably not renewed at the same level. You may recall, FINAME right now is 4.5% financing. And of course, time will tell, but since we don't know, we're, I think, a little more cautious on the, in particular, the fourth quarter.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bernstein. Let me ask first about the facility in Russia. You said that it's continuing on plan. I guess my question is, even if the credit issues in Russia and Eastern Europe don't really start to ease in the next six months, when that facility starts to
componenttext: Bernstein. Let me ask first about the facility in Russia. You said that it's continuing on plan. I guess my question is, even if the credit issues in Russia and Eastern Europe don't really start to ease in the next six months, when that facility starts to operate, are you still going to have to stock the dealers or are those dealers actually already stocked and there's not really demand for tractors out of those facilities until retail demand actually picks up?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: It would probably depend by product. First of all, we're talking about getting these -- we're going full steam. This facility will be open in the spring. You're going to have missed part of the season. So this gives us the time to ramp up. So we're not lo
componenttext: It would probably depend by product. First of all, we're talking about getting these -- we're going full steam. This facility will be open in the spring. You're going to have missed part of the season. So this gives us the time to ramp up. So we're not looking for high level of sales candidly as we start to ramp up. We're going to one product, make sure we get it right, do the next one. If financing is showing some signs of easing in Russia, it's much more difficult than other countries. But interest rates have come down and so there are a few glimmers now. We're talking at the margins so don't get too excited. But there are some signs here. Our dealers do have some products that was there before liquidity crisis. So there's some product in-country help facilitate activity in this period of transition, if you will.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the way to think about this is, there's some dealer restocking in the back half of 2010 probably creating positive year-on-year comps, but the real gain is recovery in 2011, assuming their credit crisis continues?
componenttext: So the way to think about this is, there's some dealer restocking in the back half of 2010 probably creating positive year-on-year comps, but the real gain is recovery in 2011, assuming their credit crisis continues?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Deere's First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Ms. Marie Ziegler, Vice President, Investor Relations.
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Deere's First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Ms. Marie Ziegler, Vice President, Investor Relations.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Also on today's call are Jim Field, our Chief Financial Officer; and Susan Karlix and Justin Merrimac from the Deere Investor Relations staff. Today, we'll take a closer look at Deere's first quarter earnings and then spend some time talking
componenttext: Good morning. Also on today's call are Jim Field, our Chief Financial Officer; and Susan Karlix and Justin Merrimac from the Deere Investor Relations staff. Today, we'll take a closer look at Deere's first quarter earnings and then spend some time talking about our markets and provide you an update on how we see 2010 is shaping up. After that, we will open for questions. Please note that slides are available to complement the call this morning. They can be accessed on our website at www.johndeere.com. First as usual, a reminder. This call is being broadcast live on the Internet and recorded for future transmission and use by Deere and Thomson Reuters. Any other use, recording, or transmission of any portion of this copyrighted broadcast without the expressed written consent of Deere is strictly prohibited. Participants in the call, including the Q&A section, agree that their license and remarks and all media, may be stored and used as part of the earnings call.Today's call includes forward-looking comments concerning the company's projections, plans and objectives for the future that are subject to important risks and uncertainties. Actual results might differ materially from those projected in these forward-looking statements. Additional information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ materially is contained in the company's most recent Form 8-K and periodic reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company, except as required by law, undertakes no obligation to update or revise these forward-looking information. The call and the company material are not an offer to sell or a solicitation of offers to buy any of the company's security.This call also may include financial measures that are not in conformance with accounting principles, generally accepted in the United States of America, otherwise known as GAAP. Additional information concerning these measures, including reconciliations to comparable GAAP measures is posted on our website at www.johndeere.com/financialreports, under Other Financial Information. Call participants should consider the other information on risks and uncertainties and non-GAAP measures, in addition to the information presented on the call. And now for a closer look at our first quarter, here's Susan.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Marie. This morning, John Deere reported results for the first quarter of 2010, and what a quarter it was. In spite of a decline in sales, earnings were up 19% from a year ago. The improvement was led by our Ag & Turf and Credit businesses, bot
componenttext: Thank you, Marie. This morning, John Deere reported results for the first quarter of 2010, and what a quarter it was. In spite of a decline in sales, earnings were up 19% from a year ago. The improvement was led by our Ag & Turf and Credit businesses, both of which are experiencing improved conditions. Disciplined costs and asset management were again major stories, with SA&G expense, a little changed and trade receivables and inventories, down by $1.4 billion. Finally, our full-year forecast for earnings has been increased significantly to $1.3 billion. All in all, it was an impressive performance. Now let's look at the quarter in more detail starting with Slide 3.First quarter net income attributable to Deere & Company was $243 million or $0.57 per share on net sales and revenues of $4.8 billion. It was the second highest earnings total for any first quarter in the company's history, trailing only the first quarter of 2008. As shown on Slide 4, total worldwide Equipment Operations net sales were down 7% in the first quarter versus first quarter of 2009. Currency translation on net sales was positive by about five points, with about two points of positive price realization.Turning to Slide 5, worldwide production tonnage was down 20% in the quarter. However, demand has been better than expected for large Ag and international Forestry product, accounting for the improvement in our tonnage forecast. For the full year, projected production tonnage is now forecast to be up about 5%. Let's turn to the company outlook on Slide 6. Second quarter sales are expected to be up 4% to 6% compared with the second quarter of 2009. Currency translation is expected to be positive by about five points, with about two points of positive price realization. For the full year, net equipment sales are forecast to be up 6% to 8% compared with fiscal year 2009. This includes about three points of positive currency translation and one to two points of positive price realization. Net income attributable to Deere & Company is now forecast to be about $1.3 billion for the year.Turning to a review of our individual businesses, let's start with Agriculture & Turf on Slide 7. In the quarter, net sales were down 6%, with production tonnage down 20%. Operating profit was $352 million in the quarter. Lower raw material costs, positive price realizations and the favorable effects of foreign currency translation and product mix, offset lower sales volumes and higher post-retirement benefit costs. A&T is starting to see benefits from last year's organizational realignment, resulting in the creation of the Ag & Turf division. Ongoing rationalization of processes, facilities and resources is allowing the division to more efficiently meet customer needs and reduce overall costs.Before we review the sales outlook, let's look at some of the fundamentals affecting the Ag business starting on Slide 8. Commodity prices for the '09, '10 crop have risen modestly since our last forecast. Corn acreage is expected to increase 1.5 million acres in 2010 to meet growing demand for feed, export and ethanol. What's more? Corn is expected to be more profitable this year. According to Informa, profits from corn will be $77 an acre more than soybeans in 2010. This is an additional $15 an acre above the 2009 levels.For soybeans, continued robust export demand will keep prices relatively high in the near term. Finally, cotton prices remain well above the year ago level, driven by lower production in Asia and the rapidly recovering Asian economy. Turning to Slide 9, forecast prices as you can see are below the very high levels of 2008, but remain strong on a historical basis. On Slide 10, 2010 U.S. farm cash receipts are now forecast to be up about 4% from 2009 levels. The biggest changes in the Livestock sector were milk prices have continued to climb and things are generally headed in the right direction.Slide 11 highlights farm net income in Brazil and Argentina. Argentina is recovering from the 2009 drought, driving increased demand for tractors, combines, sprayers and storage equipment. In Brazil, 2010 farm net income is expected to double from last year's level. Normally, when we talk about Brazil, we talk about soybeans. However, the primary driver if increased farm net income in 2010 is the large improvement in sugar. International sugar prices are extremely strong. Demand is higher than production due to a drastic drought-driven reduction in sugar output from India and China. Strong demand for sugar is only part of the story in Brazil. Other positive factors include demand for Brazilian commodities globally, as well as government sponsored low rate finance programs like FINAME and Mais Alimentos. These are all contributing to positive producer attitudes, which translate into higher spending on farm equipment.Putting all that together, as you can see on Slide 12, our outlook for industry sales of agricultural equipment in the U.S. and Canada is comparable to 2009. This is up significantly from our previous forecast of down about 10%. The strength we've seen in our order book is driving this increase. For example, the combine early order program ended in January with a significantly higher than expected response rate. Demand for large tractors has been higher than expected as well. On the 8R Series Tractor, we have added schedule as orders have come in, effective availability in September 2010. The story is same on the 9000 Series Tractors, with effective availability in May 2010. Conditions in Western Europe are weak, with Ag sales there expected to be down 10% to 15% in the year. Farmer sentiment is low and used equipment inventories remain high due to the lack of products going to Central Europe. We expect sales in Central Europe and the CIS to remain under pressure as well. Things look better in South America, where sales are projected to increase 10% to 15%.  Turning to another product category, we expect retail sales of Turf equipment and compact utility tractors in the U.S. and Canada to be flat for the year, after a sharp drop in 2009.On Slide 13, Deere sales for worldwide Ag & Turf are projected to be up 4% to 6% in the year versus our previous forecast of down about 4%. Currency translation is projected to be positive about four points. As just discussed, demand for large Ag equipment is much stronger than anticipated. Product mix has shifted in our favor as well. In November, we talked about product mix, referring to sales of different categories of equipment being a factor in our lower 2010 outlook. At the time, we expected sales of large Ag products to be down almost 10%, with the large absorption of these products negatively affecting operating margins. In our current forecast, the anticipated improvement in large Ag will change the mix. We now expect mix to be neutral in 2010.The division will benefit from operating improvements made in 2009, as well as from positive price realization, lower material costs and the positive effects of currency. Conversely, about $300 million of the increase in pension OPEB expense will be charged to Ag & Turf. Also, the division will see higher R&D expense, primarily for Interim Tier 4, the Regulatory Engine Emission Standards in the U.S. and Stage III B in Europe.In Turf, we are encouraged by strong retail demand in commercial mowing and golf and turf equipment in January. For the year, the A&T division's operating margin is forecast to be around 10%. Let's focus now on Construction & Forestry on Slide 14.With continuing weak markets in the U.S. and abroad, net sales were down 15% in the quarter. Production tonnage was down 22%. The division reported an operating loss of $37 million. Again this quarter, C&F demonstrated commitment to its trough management plan through tight expense control but higher pension and OPEB expense, as well as higher R&D expense, mainly associated with Interim Tier 4 spending resulted in a decremental margin of about 50%. Without these two items, C&F's decremental margin would have been in the mid-20s. Through the aggressive management of production level, the division has continued to successfully manage inventories. At the end of January, based on inventory levels reported to the Association of Equipment Manufacturers, Deere Construction dealers in the U.S. and Canada were carrying about 1/3 less the inventory than the rest of the industry based on percent of days on hand.On Slide 15, Construction & Forestry sales are now expected to be up about 21% in 2010, up from the very low levels of 2009 and from our previous forecast of up about 18%. On the Construction side as you see from the chart, U.S. economic indicators for 2010 indicate the retail market will remain weak. Non-residential spending is forecast to be down again in 2010 due to ripple effects from the depressed housing sector coupled with tight credit conditions. Overall, we believe the retail market for Construction Equipment will be down 5% to 10% in 2010. Things are looking a little better however, for global forestry markets. Improving global economic conditions, better pulp prices and low-field inventories will benefit the Forestry segment in 2010. Again, this is in comparison with the very low levels of 2009. Deere's C&F division will benefit from higher production and sales. However, these will be offset by a higher charge of about $100 million for pension and OPEB expense. Other headwinds include higher R&D expenses, primarily for Interim Tier 4, as well as a possible material cost increase and roughly flat pricing. As a result, the C&F division's operating margins are expected to be similar to 2009.Let's move now to our credit operations. Slide 16 shows the worldwide credit operations provision for credit losses as a percent of the total average portfolio. In the first quarter, the provision on an annualized basis ran 52 basis points. Write-offs in the Construction & Forestry portfolios were lower than expected and lower than a year ago in absolute dollars. While this is encouraging, we aren't prepared to say we've turned the corner. The full-year provision is still forecast to run around 89 basis points, roughly the same as last year.On Slide 17, past dues for the worldwide Credit operation are about flat with last year. Annualized write-offs continue to reflect the excellent performance of our Ag portfolio. The Construction & Forestry rate has increased, but as noted a few moments ago, write-offs in dollars are lower than a year ago. The percentage is higher because the portfolio, the denominator, is lower. This reflects the steep decline in U.S. Construction Equipment sales since 2006.Moving to Slide 18, worldwide Credit operations net income attributable to Deere & Company was $81 million in the quarter versus $45 million last year. The biggest factor was an improvement in financing spreads. This resulted from interest rates returning to more historical spreads following the interest rate volatility in late 2008 and early 2009. Looking ahead, we are projecting worldwide Credit operations net income attributable to Deere & Company of about $260 million in 2010.Now let's turn our focus back to the equipment operations and take a look at receivables and inventory on Slide 19. For the company as a whole, receivables and inventories were down roughly $1.4 billion in the quarter. Since our last outlook, in light of the higher than anticipated production levels expected in the fourth quarter, we are forecasting receivables and inventory to be up about $450 million in 2010. Now let's discuss the latest on retail sales.Slide 20 presents the product category details for the month of January expressed in units. Utility tractor industry sales were down 7%. Deere was down less than the industry. Row-crop tractor industry sales were up 32%, Deere was up more than the industry. Four-wheel-drive tractor industry sales were up 5%. Deere was up a single-digit but more than the industry. Combine industry sales were up 14%. Deere was up more than the industry. Looking at Deere dealer inventories in the bottom chart for row-crop tractors, Deere ended January with inventories at 21% of trailing 12 month sales. Combine inventories were at 6% of sales. As January percentage trailing 12 months retail sales have seen a slight uptick for row crop tractors year-over-year. At the end of January, the absolute number of units in inventory for both row-crop tractors and combines, as a percent of trailing 12 month sales, was lower than a year ago.Turning to Slide 21. In Western Europe, sales of John Deere tractors were down double digits and combines were up double digits in January. Deere's retail sales of selected Turf and utility equipment in the U.S. and Canada were up a single-digit in the month. Construction & Forestry sales in the U.S. and Canada on both first-in-the-dirt and settlement basis were down double digits for the month.Slide 22 shows raw material and logistics costs down about $160 million in the quarter. We now forecast material cost decreases of approximately $150 million for the year. This is slightly lower than our previous forecast, reflecting higher commodity price projections for inputs like steel. This estimate could deteriorate further if commodity prices rise more than anticipated and the dollar weakens from its present level. The Ag & Turf division savings is forecasted at about $150 million. For Construction & Forestry, due to the currency impact on partner products, we are now forecasting C&F material costs to be flat to up $25 million.Looking at R&D expense on Slide 23, R&D was up about 7% in the first quarter, with currency translation accounting for about two points. R&D expense is expected to be up about 12% in fiscal 2010 with currency accounting for about one point. The bulk of the increase is accounted for by Interim Tier 4 emission spending.Moving now to Slide 24, pension expense in the first quarter was about $110 million. As discussed last quarter, the 2010 forecast calls for an increase of about $400 million in pension and OPEB expense, primarily due to a change in the discount rate. Of the $400 million change, about $325 million will hit cost of sales, leading about $75 million in SA&G. Ag & Turf has responsibility for about $300 million of the additional expense while the increase for C&F is about $100 million.On Slide 25, equipment operations SA&G expense was up about 1% in the quarter. Currency translation accounted for about four points. Pension and OPEB added about three points. Excluding these two items, SA&G expense would've been down about six points in the quarter. For fiscal 2010, we now project SA&G to be up about eight points. Pension and OPEB accounts for about three points. Variable incentive compensation contributes about three points of the change and currency about two points.Moving to the tax rate on Slide 26. The implied first quarter tax rate for the equipment operations was about 36%. For 2010, the full-year effective tax rate is expected to be in the range of 34% to 35%. Before touching on cash flow, currency movements, both translation and transactions or trade flows increased operating profit by about $75 million in the first quarter.On Slide 27, you see the strong cash flow from our equipment operations even in years of tough market conditions. This reflects in large part, our success managing assets and controlling working capital levels. We anticipate strong cash flow from the equipment operations in 2010, $1.9 billion, up from last year's $1.4 billion. Such strong cash flow is further testament to the execution and success of the SVA model.On Slide 28, capital expenditures are now expected to be about $900 million, primarily driven by Interim Tier 4. Depreciation and amortization is projected to be about $600 million. Our forecast currently includes about $600 million of pension and OPEB contributions in the year and capital spending for financial services is forecasted around $200 million in 2010, primarily for wind projects. In closing, John Deere has started 2010 on a strongly positive note and is looking for further improvement in the year ahead. Our performance in the face of stubbornly weak global economic conditions reflects the solid execution of our operating and marketing plans, and our success in taking costs and asset discipline to a new level. We remained squarely focused on our customers as well, expanding our global customer base and extending our competitive position. As a result of these factors, we continue to believe that our company is well prepared to capitalize on an eventual upturn in the economy and well-positioned to meet the world's growing need for food, fuel, shelter and infrastructure in the years to come.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
