headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Jamie Cook. [Credit Suisse]
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Jamie Cook. [Credit Suisse]

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Marie, can you give any more color in the first quarter how much, can you quantify what the material cost benefit was in the first quarter when we think about the Ag margins and just how that plays out throughout the year because I'm perplexed by your fla
componenttext: Marie, can you give any more color in the first quarter how much, can you quantify what the material cost benefit was in the first quarter when we think about the Ag margins and just how that plays out throughout the year because I'm perplexed by your flat margin comment for Ag for the full year? And then the other question would just be, just a little more color on what you're seeing on Western European trends within farm. You didn't change your top line forecast but sort of how you're thinking about your inventory levels and production relative to the industry and any color you can give by country?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Why don't we start with Western Europe first. Farmer moved there continues to be pretty somber. And as a result, you'll note that we have not changed our guidance, which is the industry will be down 10% to 15%. We do see some differences in some countries
componenttext: Why don't we start with Western Europe first. Farmer moved there continues to be pretty somber. And as a result, you'll note that we have not changed our guidance, which is the industry will be down 10% to 15%. We do see some differences in some countries because of the currency relationships. You do see some a little bit more strengthened in places like the U.K. and Poland because their currencies are -- the farm on these [ph] are paid in euros and the currencies are relatively stronger. But generally speaking, livestock is maybe stabilizing, some that stabilizing at pretty low levels and you continue to see a backup of used equipment. But we've cited this a couple of times in the calls before, it's not yet at worrisome levels but it does act as the cautionary note in the market. Moving on to margins, our raw material guidance is $150 million for the year and basically, we got it all in the first quarter and generally speaking, flat through the rest of the year. You'll note too that when we talk about things like R&D and SA&G, we're relatively light in the first quarter. Those costs will increase at least as what forecast has been doing as you move through the year, and of course Ag, is the bigger piece to both of those numbers.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: There are really factors, even though their sales are up, basically that incremental margin is absorbed by about $100 million pension and OPEB increase, which we had talked about last quarter's net still in play. They too have higher R&D and is actually f
componenttext: There are really factors, even though their sales are up, basically that incremental margin is absorbed by about $100 million pension and OPEB increase, which we had talked about last quarter's net still in play. They too have higher R&D and is actually for the divisions of the full year it's about $40 million. So it's not insignificant. And they have just one other factor -- material cost we have a headwind of flat to up about $25 million. So the mid a point of that would be, what? 10 to 15.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And that's just wiping out all of the profitability?
componenttext: And that's just wiping out all of the profitability?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Basically that absorbs it all.
componenttext: Basically that absorbs it all.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: You have increased Ag production significantly. And I think if you reference at the fourth quarter, it's going to be much higher. Can you give us an insight to have the Ag sales a look for the rest of the year? Second quarter obviously, probably still be
componenttext: You have increased Ag production significantly. And I think if you reference at the fourth quarter, it's going to be much higher. Can you give us an insight to have the Ag sales a look for the rest of the year? Second quarter obviously, probably still be the strongest of the year, but in a much stronger fourth quarter now that you said it before, that was indicated?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: That really was referencing than what we anticipated. But basically versus a year ago because a year ago we were we had significant side downs. So this year, we will be in production at a higher level and that of course goes on to affect our trade receiva
componenttext: That really was referencing than what we anticipated. But basically versus a year ago because a year ago we were we had significant side downs. So this year, we will be in production at a higher level and that of course goes on to affect our trade receivables.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: The second quarter will still be strongest of the yea, but you do comparison second half of the what year that...
componenttext: The second quarter will still be strongest of the yea, but you do comparison second half of the what year that...

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's really more the issue, absolutely.
componenttext: That's really more the issue, absolutely.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Robert Wertheimer. [Morgan Stanley]
componenttext: Our next question comes from Robert Wertheimer. [Morgan Stanley]

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I have two questions on production schedule. The first is just how you think about it, we've been hearing and we believe underlying demand is fairly strong. Have you raise the combine production and is that done, are you pretty much going to produce what
componenttext: I have two questions on production schedule. The first is just how you think about it, we've been hearing and we believe underlying demand is fairly strong. Have you raise the combine production and is that done, are you pretty much going to produce what you're going to produce? and similar on the large tractor side, would you potentially if demand continues to be strong, pump that up again or are you aiming to hit a certain schedule?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've certainly would do anything that we could to meet our customers demand requirements. And to go back to one of your earlier point, yes, we have a pretty significantly increased our projected production for our combines and actually for large tractors
componenttext: We've certainly would do anything that we could to meet our customers demand requirements. And to go back to one of your earlier point, yes, we have a pretty significantly increased our projected production for our combines and actually for large tractors. And that, as we talk about that, is really the single biggest factor driving the change in the top line and income guidance.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've heard a couple of farmers, not a lot but a couple talking about nervousness about the Tier 4 engine, not so much of the price, but wanting somebody else to take the risk on the first year of the engine. And so are you concerned about the pre-buy, do
componenttext: We've heard a couple of farmers, not a lot but a couple talking about nervousness about the Tier 4 engine, not so much of the price, but wanting somebody else to take the risk on the first year of the engine. And so are you concerned about the pre-buy, does that affect your production decision for this year and what's your strategy for showing farmers that the engine [ph] is going to work how you're going to roll that out?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've already been at farm shows, starting to introduce the product. We're starting to get news on magazine articles, talking about the production. I would like at anytime you have a major change in the machine there's always some customers who want the f
componenttext: We've already been at farm shows, starting to introduce the product. We're starting to get news on magazine articles, talking about the production. I would like at anytime you have a major change in the machine there's always some customers who want the first in technology. There would be some interesting product benefits and some of the products that comes along with it and there is a tremendous need to continue to improve productivity. We, over the long-term, need to increase food for the world. And so I would say that this is something that we manage through before. We will be doing -- we have a very significant rollout plan in terms of training, and education to our dealers and technicians and of course for customers, who have plenty of opportunities.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Marie, the hit on this training -- and this is a huge undertaking, we've got 20 different courses. we're rolling out in 14 different languages. We've already touched more than 8,000 dealer personnel. And so all that is really about educating the folks tha
componenttext: Marie, the hit on this training -- and this is a huge undertaking, we've got 20 different courses. we're rolling out in 14 different languages. We've already touched more than 8,000 dealer personnel. And so all that is really about educating the folks that are at the front-line interaction with the customers to help the customers get the level of confidence that they need, and to make sure that we can deliver the John Deere experience. So it's a huge undertaking.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ann Duignan.[JPMorgan]
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ann Duignan.[JPMorgan]

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Marie, it's kind of a double-edged sword that -- whomever wants to address this -- that currency is positively impacting your outlook for equipment sales. However, the double-edged sword is a stronger dollar could impact both your equipment exports, as we
componenttext: Marie, it's kind of a double-edged sword that -- whomever wants to address this -- that currency is positively impacting your outlook for equipment sales. However, the double-edged sword is a stronger dollar could impact both your equipment exports, as well as soft commodity exports. Can you talk a little bit about what exactly is in your outlook for currency, particularly euro-dollar exchange rate and what's the upside versus the downside risk that you see with that forecast?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Specifically, we do have a practice of not forecasting what the currency will do. And so we look at the rate that we have experienced in the quarter and use that to forecast, going forward. And that would've been a euro that was 1 40 or -- 1 46 was the av
componenttext: Specifically, we do have a practice of not forecasting what the currency will do. And so we look at the rate that we have experienced in the quarter and use that to forecast, going forward. And that would've been a euro that was 1 40 or -- 1 46 was the average.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: 1 46 was the average rate for the quarter, and that's what we used, going forward.
componenttext: 1 46 was the average rate for the quarter, and that's what we used, going forward.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: For the company, in terms of Europe, specifically, the primary tractor in Europe is the mid-size tractor and those are manufactured in Europe. That's the primary source for this. So we do a fairly good job of trying to match production to where the market
componenttext: For the company, in terms of Europe, specifically, the primary tractor in Europe is the mid-size tractor and those are manufactured in Europe. That's the primary source for this. So we do a fairly good job of trying to match production to where the markets are.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: You did benefit last cycle though from significant exports of combines out of North America into places like Eastern Europe.
componenttext: You did benefit last cycle though from significant exports of combines out of North America into places like Eastern Europe.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Eastern Europe and Russia, that's a whole different set of circumstances. Go ahead, Jim.
componenttext: Well, Eastern Europe and Russia, that's a whole different set of circumstances. Go ahead, Jim.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And a lot of those transactions will be denominated in dollars as well.
componenttext: And a lot of those transactions will be denominated in dollars as well.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Ann, you're aware that the single biggest factor in our outlook there is the circumstances in Russia. And we're working to get up an assembly facility up and running. We're on time for that, we said in the spring, and we're working with the Russian go
componenttext: And Ann, you're aware that the single biggest factor in our outlook there is the circumstances in Russia. And we're working to get up an assembly facility up and running. We're on time for that, we said in the spring, and we're working with the Russian government to make sure we all understand the terms. So we're on track there, too.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then my follow-up question is a similar question but on interest rates. Interest rates have helped support very aggressive pricing out there in the marketplace not just from John Deere, but from competitors at large. And it has been a positive for you
componenttext: And then my follow-up question is a similar question but on interest rates. Interest rates have helped support very aggressive pricing out there in the marketplace not just from John Deere, but from competitors at large. And it has been a positive for your Financial Services business. Can you talk a little bit about your outlook for interest rates, going forward, and how that might impact your Financial Services business?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: We -- I don't think really have been out front with a explicit forecast. But our financial services business is all about -- we don't really take positions on rates so much. We try to lock in finance for it, and be a match-funded such that these swings, u
componenttext: We -- I don't think really have been out front with a explicit forecast. But our financial services business is all about -- we don't really take positions on rates so much. We try to lock in finance for it, and be a match-funded such that these swings, unless they happen very quickly and/or very violently, that they don't impact the earnings stream too much. Having said that, in general, our view would be for a increasing rate environment over the course of the year. And that would be a very, very modest view, though. And we have factored that into some of our forecast on the financial services side, but also on the equipment side because that generally results in higher interest waiver charges.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Henry Kirn [ph].
componenttext: Our next question comes from Henry Kirn [ph].

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't cite it so much as a pre-buy because we know that the primary drivers of customer demand are good levels of cash receipts to the farm income. And you certainly would agree, going back to Ann's comments, lower interest rates certainly have also
componenttext: I wouldn't cite it so much as a pre-buy because we know that the primary drivers of customer demand are good levels of cash receipts to the farm income. And you certainly would agree, going back to Ann's comments, lower interest rates certainly have also helped support that. You are aware that we had put additional capacity on both Harvester and at Waterloo last year and actually at many, many of our factories globally. So we have the ability to respond to additional demand. That said, for our combine program in the U.S. and Canada, round numbers, 95% of our orders are already in place and we adjust production accordingly based on the results of our early-order program. So we could have some additional flexing there, but we're pretty well in position there.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, that is included in the benefits that we are citing because as we merged the two divisions together, there were people redundancies and processes that were improved really out of both sides of the business. We don't exist as two separate silos anymo
componenttext: Well, that is included in the benefits that we are citing because as we merged the two divisions together, there were people redundancies and processes that were improved really out of both sides of the business. We don't exist as two separate silos anymore. They're really fully-merged. And that's what generating for this year a $50 million to $60 million charge. I would just talk about the Landscapes business, too. They have very difficult market conditions because they are very focused on housing and driven by housing. And that business has unfortunately also had slight reductions, those who are at the bottom [ph], 800 people even to 1,000. And they've got closed emerged store locations, so they also are looking for some improvement in their financial results. And that is may be an additional $25 million this year. And then finally, you're aware that we closed our facility in Welland, and we're really in the final phases of that. And so there's some operating savings this year, assuming a pretax of about $40 million.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Steve Volkmann.[Jefferies & Company]
componenttext: Our next question comes from Steve Volkmann.[Jefferies & Company]

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm just curious, what happened since your last forecast that you gave us that led to such better margin? I guess, it was all in the margin, but something must have really changed since the lens [ph] you were looking through in November was kind of just s
componenttext: I'm just curious, what happened since your last forecast that you gave us that led to such better margin? I guess, it was all in the margin, but something must have really changed since the lens [ph] you were looking through in November was kind of just so far off. How did the quarter evolve?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Really, in terms of the sales outlook for the year, the single biggest driver was that our order book developed pretty dramatically over the course of the first quarter and enabled us to improve our outlook for the industry from down then to basically fla
componenttext: Really, in terms of the sales outlook for the year, the single biggest driver was that our order book developed pretty dramatically over the course of the first quarter and enabled us to improve our outlook for the industry from down then to basically flat. So that's the single biggest driver.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And at a much different level than that, because that's a single biggest driver, but we also experienced a more favorable currency than we would've built into those original estimates.
componenttext: And at a much different level than that, because that's a single biggest driver, but we also experienced a more favorable currency than we would've built into those original estimates.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: In the quarter. I was about to remind everyone, that was about a $75 million translation in transaction benefit in the first quarter.
componenttext: In the quarter. I was about to remind everyone, that was about a $75 million translation in transaction benefit in the first quarter.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe this is for Jim but whoever wants to take it. We've talked a little bit about how you have a lot of liquidity on the balance sheet. You're obviously continuing to generate a lot of cash. At some point, some of that cash, I guess, becomes available f
componenttext: Maybe this is for Jim but whoever wants to take it. We've talked a little bit about how you have a lot of liquidity on the balance sheet. You're obviously continuing to generate a lot of cash. At some point, some of that cash, I guess, becomes available for things like share repurchases or dividends or even acquisitions. But I think you've said that you wanted to kind of wait and see how things evolve in the financial markets. Has there been any evolution over the last few months?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say, first of all, you're right on. That's what we said. And I would say we have this well-articulated use-of-cash policy and one of the uses of cash that we talked about also is making sure that our pension plans are fully-funded. And so we did i
componenttext: I would say, first of all, you're right on. That's what we said. And I would say we have this well-articulated use-of-cash policy and one of the uses of cash that we talked about also is making sure that our pension plans are fully-funded. And so we did increase funding to the pension plans by about $250 million in terms of the forecast. In terms of how we view the world, I think we still think we're on a relatively fragile foundation. In the fourth quarter '09, we were all shocked by the whole home device [ph]  Situation and what the implications of that may have been for the capital markets. And then, of course, then we move into the first quarter, and we get the Eurozone issue. Having said that, we are targeting -- we had about 12-month target of pre-funding at the end of '09, and we will be coming off that moving more into the six to nine-month range by '10, by the end of this year.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Alex Blanton.[Ingalls & Snyder]
componenttext: Our next question comes from Alex Blanton.[Ingalls & Snyder]

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Marie, in the last conference call in November, you talked about the construction, forestry seeming to be up 18%, and factory sales with the retail sales, down 5% to 10%. And you basically made the same forecast this time, except saying that the factory s
componenttext: Marie, in the last conference call in November, you talked about the construction, forestry seeming to be up 18%, and factory sales with the retail sales, down 5% to 10%. And you basically made the same forecast this time, except saying that the factory sales would be up 21% and the retail sales, again, down 5% to 10%. So if that is primarily due to a lower inventory reduction year-over-year, maybe a flat inventory versus a huge inventory reduction last year at the dealer level, now can we then take that concept and talk about the Ag business? What's happening at the dealer level in Ag inventory? And maybe you already mentioned this, but I didn't hear it, how much of the change in sales of Ag equipment might be due to less inventory reduction at the dealer level than last year?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: We aren't expecting any reduction in inventories in the Ag business at year-over-year and 30 of October [ph]. In fact, at the dealer level, we'll probably have at least our forecast has receivables and inventories up about $415 million. That's our guidanc
componenttext: We aren't expecting any reduction in inventories in the Ag business at year-over-year and 30 of October [ph]. In fact, at the dealer level, we'll probably have at least our forecast has receivables and inventories up about $415 million. That's our guidance at year end. And most of that will be in Ag receivables and it will simply be because we'll have a little bit more in the pipeline than we did a year ago.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: But how much of your factory sales change is due to lower inventory reduction than last year?
componenttext: But how much of your factory sales change is due to lower inventory reduction than last year?

componenttextpreview: There's no inventory reduction this...
componenttext: There's no inventory reduction this...

componenttextpreview: I know that, you said that. But what's the difference between this year and last year in the dealer inventory reduction?
componenttext: I know that, you said that. But what's the difference between this year and last year in the dealer inventory reduction?

componenttext: We have to go back and look at how much we reduced the receivables by --

componenttext: Just inventory, not receivables --

componenttext: But the receivables is the best indication of what's going on with the deals inventory.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, maybe, but I'm trying to determine how much of your change in your production forecast for this year is due to lower inventory reduction at the dealer level than the year before.
componenttext: Well, maybe, but I'm trying to determine how much of your change in your production forecast for this year is due to lower inventory reduction at the dealer level than the year before.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Alex, I don't have that with me. I will be happy to call you back afterwards, and we'll get your question addressed.
componenttext: Alex, I don't have that with me. I will be happy to call you back afterwards, and we'll get your question addressed.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Raso. [International Strategy and Investment Group]
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Raso. [International Strategy and Investment Group]

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: My question relates to your Ag & Turf outlook. What you reported in the first quarter and what you're seeing for the full year implies the next three quarters, the rest of the year, your Ag & Turf sales are up nearly 8%, but your operating profit margins
componenttext: My question relates to your Ag & Turf outlook. What you reported in the first quarter and what you're seeing for the full year implies the next three quarters, the rest of the year, your Ag & Turf sales are up nearly 8%, but your operating profit margins are down about 60 bps year-over-year. And it looks like from what you're implying about costs, generally neutral the rest of the year on a year-over-year basis, pricing, up, for the whole company up about $220 million, rest of year -- I have to assume a lot of that's Ag, not construction.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's fair.
componenttext: That's fair.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And what am I missing why your margins would be down the rest of the year, year-over-year?
componenttext: And what am I missing why your margins would be down the rest of the year, year-over-year?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: The increase in R&D, which was up 7%. In the first quarter, it's up 12%. Higher SA&G, which was basically, I think, was up like 1% in the quarter. And our guidance has it up for the full year, SA&G for the year, up 8%. So basically that's all back-end loa
componenttext: The increase in R&D, which was up 7%. In the first quarter, it's up 12%. Higher SA&G, which was basically, I think, was up like 1% in the quarter. And our guidance has it up for the full year, SA&G for the year, up 8%. So basically that's all back-end loaded.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: That would be powerful enough to offset obviously the mix, sounds like it's improving?
componenttext: That would be powerful enough to offset obviously the mix, sounds like it's improving?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's neutral.
componenttext: It's neutral.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And price versus cost sounds like it's almost 100, 150 bps year-over-year improvement for the rest of the year as well.
componenttext: And price versus cost sounds like it's almost 100, 150 bps year-over-year improvement for the rest of the year as well.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Remember, the Ag division will eat about $300 million more of pension. Now some of that is both through SA&G so I don't want to [indiscernible] about 60% of that increase actually goes into cost of sales. So you wouldn't be picking up any SA&G. And that i
componenttext: Remember, the Ag division will eat about $300 million more of pension. Now some of that is both through SA&G so I don't want to [indiscernible] about 60% of that increase actually goes into cost of sales. So you wouldn't be picking up any SA&G. And that is -- I mean, there's nothing else, these are just claims. Straightforward, those are the items that eat out that additional market.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I guess related to that, the pricing on the products in backlog in the order book, obviously, there's been no change since prices at last fall, generally speaking, right? So if I'm getting better or large equipment, which is where we you got the prici
componenttext: And I guess related to that, the pricing on the products in backlog in the order book, obviously, there's been no change since prices at last fall, generally speaking, right? So if I'm getting better or large equipment, which is where we you got the pricing, unless you try to get the pricing, we'll think it's coming through with the order book, the way it is. Again, I'm specially surprised that you would think that the offset from SG&A and so forth would actually give you down margins when Waterloo, Harvester Works...

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: We increased our guidance for the overall Ag division. Our previous guidance has been similar to what we've done last year. And now we're seeing about 10%. So it's a bit of an improvement. There [indiscernible] coming to the bottom line there.
componenttext: We increased our guidance for the overall Ag division. Our previous guidance has been similar to what we've done last year. And now we're seeing about 10%. So it's a bit of an improvement. There [indiscernible] coming to the bottom line there.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: True, but again at the end of day, the rest of the year, sales are implied up 7.8% for Ag & Turf. Volume margins are at 10.1%, and you did 10.7% the last three quarters of last year.
componenttext: True, but again at the end of day, the rest of the year, sales are implied up 7.8% for Ag & Turf. Volume margins are at 10.1%, and you did 10.7% the last three quarters of last year.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we didn't have the pension in the SA&G and R&D. It's simple as that, David.
componenttext: Well, we didn't have the pension in the SA&G and R&D. It's simple as that, David.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Barry Bannister.[Stifel, Nicolaus]
componenttext: Our next question comes from Barry Bannister.[Stifel, Nicolaus]

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just want to follow up on David Raso's question. If as you forecast the 60-bp decline in operating margin against the 7.8% increase in sales, when I look at the SA&G guidance for last year versus fiscal 2010, previously, the only real change is variable
componenttext: I just want to follow up on David Raso's question. If as you forecast the 60-bp decline in operating margin against the 7.8% increase in sales, when I look at the SA&G guidance for last year versus fiscal 2010, previously, the only real change is variable compensation is now seeing up three whereas it was completely absent from your old forecast. So it wasn't variable compensation a major reason why Ag & Turf didn't get any margin lift on the additional volume as well?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: That would be a factor, but that's really in the SA&G and then admittedly there's some of it in cost of sales as well. But the other thing is that it's somewhat of a timing. Our SA&G came in last year, a little more uniformly than what we are currently pr
componenttext: That would be a factor, but that's really in the SA&G and then admittedly there's some of it in cost of sales as well. But the other thing is that it's somewhat of a timing. Our SA&G came in last year, a little more uniformly than what we are currently projecting this year. Again, we had almost flat in the first quarter, and yet you're looking for a gain in over the course of the year. So you're going to have a bigger increase year-over-year in quarters two through four.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, but even though you had a plus four prior forecast for FX, now it's plus two so what you picked up there was 200 bps, but your variable comp went from zero to plus three, which --
componenttext: Yes, but even though you had a plus four prior forecast for FX, now it's plus two so what you picked up there was 200 bps, but your variable comp went from zero to plus three, which --

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: For the company in whole, it's about $100 million.
componenttext: For the company in whole, it's about $100 million.

componenttextpreview: And where does it lie in Ag & Turf? I mean, what's their take since they're obviously doing better than anybody else?
componenttext: And where does it lie in Ag & Turf? I mean, what's their take since they're obviously doing better than anybody else?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: They get the bulk of it. And some of it goes in the cost of sales and some of it goes into SA&G and there's a little bit R&D, but basically it's cost of sales.
componenttext: They get the bulk of it. And some of it goes in the cost of sales and some of it goes into SA&G and there's a little bit R&D, but basically it's cost of sales.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Joel Tiss.[Buckingham Research]
componenttext: And our next question comes from Joel Tiss.[Buckingham Research]

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just wondered if you can spend a minute to break apart the Construction & Forestry and talk about the different trends in those different end markets?
componenttext: I just wondered if you can spend a minute to break apart the Construction & Forestry and talk about the different trends in those different end markets?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, Forestry accounts for the improvement in the Construction & Forestry outlook. We originally had said our sales would be up 18, now we're seeing up 21 and really it's because we are starting to see a better ordering activity. Principally, it's co
componenttext: Actually, Forestry accounts for the improvement in the Construction & Forestry outlook. We originally had said our sales would be up 18, now we're seeing up 21 and really it's because we are starting to see a better ordering activity. Principally, it's coming out of Europe. But now we're talking about extremely low levels, really, in forestry across the globe last year. Just trying to see a little bit of improvement. On the construction side, there was actually no change from our previous forecast. So all the incremental change occurred on the forestry side.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and dually, customers -- I've actually looked through the comments, they're talking about good farm income. They're talking about the need to maintain their normal trading cycles. We hypothesized, in fact, that maybe some of the very difficult condit
componenttext: Yes, and dually, customers -- I've actually looked through the comments, they're talking about good farm income. They're talking about the need to maintain their normal trading cycles. We hypothesized, in fact, that maybe some of the very difficult conditions, planting in the last few springs and then of course what happened this fall with the very late harvest, may also be supporting that. We also know that interest, low interest rates are very supportive to farmers purchasing position.

I understand the point about increasing production in the balance of the year, but your production in the first quarter was mostly in line with what you were looking for and it looks like what margins were about call it 300 to 500 basis points higher than what you anticipated in your guidance was quarter. Was it higher plant efficiency levels? Credit gains from the Ag & Turf combination? Can you give us some more color on the drivers?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just to refresh your memory -- actually, we don't have guidance by quarter anymore. So you're probably looking at us compared to other modeling. But we would not have any comments about what we thought our income would be in the first quarter. That said,
componenttext: Just to refresh your memory -- actually, we don't have guidance by quarter anymore. So you're probably looking at us compared to other modeling. But we would not have any comments about what we thought our income would be in the first quarter. That said, if you look at it year-over-year, the mix, I think, which we were thinking would be a bit of a drag for us in the Ag operations. Actually, it was a positive in the quarter. We're telling for the full year, it's neutral. It actually was about a point's positive in the quarter in the margins, year-over-year. So that would've been an improvement. Material costs came in maybe a little stronger than expected. And then the currency which had not been in the forecast, that's about a seven about million Dollar operating benefit.

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have worked for a long time very closely with our suppliers. And I think our execution in a difficult market, if you go all the way back to 2004, certainly as we were ramping up in late 2007, 2008, sort of speaks for itself. We do quarterly calls with
componenttext: We have worked for a long time very closely with our suppliers. And I think our execution in a difficult market, if you go all the way back to 2004, certainly as we were ramping up in late 2007, 2008, sort of speaks for itself. We do quarterly calls with our suppliers. Were working with them to make sure that if they have bottlenecks, we're working through them through those processes with them in the near term. We can maybe adjust some production to get things in early late, depending, to help accommodate their production. This time, and we just checked with our supply management folks again, we don't see any bottlenecks.

componenttext: Cleveland Research. I have a question on the South American outlook, just using Brazil as a proxy for overall South America, which probably is part of the answer to the question, but it looks like unit shipments for the first three months of your fiscal year are up 35% for tractors and 70% for combines and the implication of even the top end of the guidance, 15% for the market for the year actually means combines would have to be down for the final nine months of the year and tractors would be up kind of a high single-digit. So should we think about your South American outlook being conservative? Or is there something in the latter part of the year that you're expecting?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess, two things. One is that South American look is influenced by conditions in other markets. And although we see Argentina coming back, it's coming back some pretty low levels and then you have various sorted circumstances in other markets, so
componenttext: Well, I guess, two things. One is that South American look is influenced by conditions in other markets. And although we see Argentina coming back, it's coming back some pretty low levels and then you have various sorted circumstances in other markets, so that's one factor. The other thing is that FINAME, that current program end at the end of June. Our forecast anticipates that they will be renewed but probably not renewed at the same level. You may recall, FINAME right now is 4.5% financing. And of course, time will tell, but since we don't know, we're, I think, a little more cautious on the, in particular, the fourth quarter.

componenttextpreview: Bernstein. Let me ask first about the facility in Russia. You said that it's continuing on plan. I guess my question is, even if the credit issues in Russia and Eastern Europe don't really start to ease in the next six months, when that facility starts to
componenttext: Bernstein. Let me ask first about the facility in Russia. You said that it's continuing on plan. I guess my question is, even if the credit issues in Russia and Eastern Europe don't really start to ease in the next six months, when that facility starts to operate, are you still going to have to stock the dealers or are those dealers actually already stocked and there's not really demand for tractors out of those facilities until retail demand actually picks up?

headline: Deere & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: It would probably depend by product. First of all, we're talking about getting these -- we're going full steam. This facility will be open in the spring. You're going to have missed part of the season. So this gives us the time to ramp up. So we're not lo
componenttext: It would probably depend by product. First of all, we're talking about getting these -- we're going full steam. This facility will be open in the spring. You're going to have missed part of the season. So this gives us the time to ramp up. So we're not looking for high level of sales candidly as we start to ramp up. We're going to one product, make sure we get it right, do the next one. If financing is showing some signs of easing in Russia, it's much more difficult than other countries. But interest rates have come down and so there are a few glimmers now. We're talking at the margins so don't get too excited. But there are some signs here. Our dealers do have some products that was there before liquidity crisis. So there's some product in-country help facilitate activity in this period of transition, if you will.

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Deere Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Ms. Marie Ziegler, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Deere Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Ms. Marie Ziegler, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Also on today's call are Jim Field, our Chief Financial Officer; as well as Susan Karlix and Justin Merrimac from the Deere Investor Relations staff. Today, we'll take a closer look at Deere's second quarter earnings, and then spend some tim
componenttext:
Good morning. Also on today's call are Jim Field, our Chief Financial Officer; as well as Susan Karlix and Justin Merrimac from the Deere Investor Relations staff. Today, we'll take a closer look at Deere's second quarter earnings, and then spend some time talking about our markets and how we see the second half of the year shaping up. After that, we'll respond to your questions. Please note that slides are available to complement the call this morning, and they can be accessed on our website at www.johndeere.com.
First as usual, a reminder. This call is being broadcast live on the internet and recorded for future transmission and use by Deere and Thomson Reuters. Any other use, recording or transmission of any portion of this copyrighted broadcast without the expressed written consent of Deere is strictly prohibited. Participants in today's call, including the Q&A session, agreed that their likeness and remark and all media may be stored and used as part of the earnings call.
The call includes forward-looking comments concerning the company's projection, plans and objectives for the future that are subject to important risks and uncertainties. Actual results might differ materially from those projected in these forward-looking statements. Additional information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ materially is contained in the company's most recent Form 8-K and periodic reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company, except as required by law, undertakes no obligation to update or revise its forward-looking information. The call and accompanying materials are not an offer to sell or solicitation of offers to buy any of the company's security.
And finally, this call will include financial measures that are not in conformance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America known as GAAP. Additional information concerning these measures, including reconciliations to comparable GAAP measures, is posted on our website at www.johndeere.com under Financial Reports, other financial information. Call participants should consider the other information on risks and uncertainties and non-GAAP measures in addition to the information presented on the call. 
And now for a closer look at the second quarter, here's Susan.

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marie. John Deere's strong performance continued in the second quarter of 2010. Earnings were up 16% on a sales increase of 6%. Results would've been higher without a charge related to the recent enactment of U.S. Healthcare legislation. The qua
componenttext:
Thanks, Marie. John Deere's strong performance continued in the second quarter of 2010. Earnings were up 16% on a sales increase of 6%. Results would've been higher without a charge related to the recent enactment of U.S. Healthcare legislation. 
The quarter's improvement was broad based. The gain was led by Ag & Turf, but all three divisions had higher profit. Among the highlights, our Construction & Forestry business saw its first year-over-year profit increase in nine quarters.
Solid execution of our business plans was again a big story for the quarter as was disciplined cost and asset management. Trade receivables of inventory declined by some $900 million.
Finally, in line with improved business conditions, our full year earnings forecast has been increased and now totals approximately $1.6 billion. All in all, it was a productive quarter, and John Deere seems well on its way to a very good year.
Now let's look at the quarter in more detail starting with Slide 3. This is a supplemental slide illustrating the impact of the tax charge for U.S. Healthcare legislation taken in the quarter excluding the approximately $130 million charge, net income attributable to Deere & Co. would have been $677 million or $1.58 per share.
On Slide 4, we show that net income attributable to Deere & Co. on a reported basis was $547 million. As we mentioned, that was a 16% increase in profit on a 6% increase in net sales and revenues.
Turning to Slide 5. Total worldwide equipment operations net sales were up 6% to $6.5 billion, Deere's second-highest sales on record in a second quarter. Currency translation on net sales was positive by four points and price realization was positive by two points. Both equipment divisions had positive price realization in the quarter.
Turning to Slide 6. Worldwide production tonnage was up 7% in the quarter. Construction & Forestry tonnage was up considerably, in large part due to easy comparisons with the second quarter of 2009 when tonnage was down 62% from the previous year's level.
In addition, improving global economic conditions, better pulp prices and low field inventory are benefiting the Forestry segment in 2010. Tonnage outside the U.S. and Canada increased due to strength in Argentina and Brazil, China, India and Mexico. For the full year, worldwide production tonnage is now forecast to be up about 11%.
Let's turn to the company outlook on Slide 7. Third quarter sales are expected to be up 21% to 23% compared with the third quarter of 2009. In the financial forecast, currency translation on net sales is expected to be positive by about two points.
For the full year, net equipment sales are forecast to be up 11% to 13% compared with fiscal year 2009. This includes about three points of positive currency translation and approximately 1.5 points of positive price realization. This in line with our previous guidance of one to two points.
Net income attributable to Deere & Co. is now forecast to be about $1.6 billion for the year versus our prior guidance of about $1.3 billion. That includes the second quarter tax charge of approximately $130 million for U.S. healthcare legislation.
Turning to a review of our individual businesses. Let's start with Ag & Turf on Slide 8. In the quarter, net sales were up 1% and so was production tonnage. Operating profit, however, improved by nearly $250 million or 35% to $952 million. The increase was primarily due to improved price realization, higher production volume, the favorable effects of foreign exchange and lower raw material cost. These factors were partially offset by higher post-retirement benefit cost.
You might notice, we didn't include the A&T incremental margin this quarter. It calculates at about 498% due to the very large swing in operating profit on the small increase in sales. A&T executed well with an operating margin in the quarter of about 17%.
The division is benefiting again this year from strong sales of large ag equipment in the United States and Canada. Compared with a normal year, a favorable mix contributed one point of margin in the quarter.
Before we review the sales outlook, let's look at some of the fundamentals affecting the Ag business starting on Slide 9. Commodity prices for the '09/'10 crop have remained steady at attractive level since our last forecast with soybean seeing an improvement. Soybean exports have remained at good level despite a strong South American crop, and the good weather we have been experiencing here in the U.S. tends to favor more corn planting.
Cotton prices remain well above year-ago level driven by strong Chinese demand and a reduction in the global cotton supply. On Slide 10, we have included Deere's estimate of U.S. acres planted for 2010/2011. They are the same as the USDA estimates. Corn acreage is expected to increase 2.3 million acres to 88.8 million in order to meet growing demand for feed, exports and ethanol.
Turning to Slide 11. 2010 U.S. farm cash receipts are now forecast to be up about 5% from 2009 level, a slight improvement from our last forecast. Livestock is driving the increase in 2010 receipts.  The industry should finally expect profits this year after two years of losses. As you can see, 2011 farm cash receipts are expected to be up slightly from 2010 level.
Deere's outlook for the EU-27 is shown on Slide 12. We are beginning to see stabilization in this market but at very low levels. We don't expect any real recovery in 2010. Farmers' sentiment in the region remains negative. Small grain, pork and beef prices are expected to remain under pressure, and used-equipment inventories remain at high level due to the lack of product going to Central Europe. The industry forecast for 2010 unit tractor sales is slightly below levels seen during the last recession in the early 1990s.
Slide 13 highlights farm net income in Brazil and Argentina. Income from two main crops, soybean and sugarcane, drive the bulk of equipment purchases in Brazil. So going forward, we will provide a breakout of these two crops when discussing farm net income. Corn, paddy rice and cotton make up the other category.
2010 farm net income is driven by the strength in sugar due to a drastic drought-driven reduction in output from India and China. Demand for sugar, though, is only part of the story in Brazil. Other positive factors include demand for Brazilian commodities globally as well as government-sponsored low-rate finance programs like FINAME and Mais Alimentos. These are all contributing to positive producer attitude which translate into higher spending on farm equipment.
In April, the Brazilian government announced the FINAME financing program would be extended through the end of December. For loans taken through the end of June, the interest rate will remain at 4.5%. For loans taken from July through December, the interest rate will be 5.5%, still an extremely attractive rate in the Brazilian market.
Argentina is recovering from the severe 2009 drought with ag commodity production up over 40% in 2010, with farm net income about $6 billion higher than 2009. We are seeing increased demand for tractor, combines, sprayers and forage equipment. Clearly, the markets are improving and there's a lot of good news out of Brazil. 
The next two slides illustrate the long-term potential we see in the country. Slide 14 shows Deere estimates for planted acres and production of soybeans in Brazil over the next eight years. Planted acres are expected to increase about 45% and production about 60%. The story is similar for sugarcane. On Slide 15, you can see we expect sugarcane planted acres to increase about 65% and production about 55%.
To take advantage of this opportunity, Deere opened a tractor factory in Brazil in 2007 to complement our combine factory. And in 2008, we announced an $80 million expansion, adding capacity to both factories. Of course, we didn't undertake this without the buy-in of our dealers, who are committed to representing John Deere and willing to invest in their own businesses.
Moving to Slide 16. You can see we have added almost 70 dealer locations in the last six years. And on Slide 17, we have expanded our product offerings to meet the needs of our customers. In fact, in 2010 and 2011, we will add 50 new or updated products to our lineup, covering a broad array of categories, from tractors and combines to turf equipment and precision technology. It's an exciting picture for Brazil, and it's clear why Deere and its dealers are looking forward to the opportunity that lies ahead and preserving our growing customer base there.
Turning to another great opportunity for John Deere as you can see on Slide 18. On the heels of a slight pickup in activity and loosening of liquidity in Russia, John Deere celebrated the grand opening of its Domodedovo manufacturing and parts center outside of Moscow last month. We began limited assembly of large tractor, combines, motor graders and 4WD loaders.
Slide 19 highlights our 2010 industry outlook. Sales of agricultural equipment in the U.S. and Canada are now forecasted to be up 5% to 10%. That's quite a change from our February forecast of comparable to 2009, and our November 2009 forecast of down about 10%.
We continue to see our order books strengthen especially for large ag equipment. Remember, the combine early order program ended in January with a significantly higher-than-expected response rate. Demand for large tractors has been higher than expected as well.
The new 8R Series tractor has been very well received in the marketplace. We have continued to add schedules throughout the first half of the year and effective availability is November 2010. Effective availability for the 9000 Series tractors is September 2010.
Conditions in Western Europe remain weak with ag sales there is still expected to be down 10% to 15% in the year. Although Russia is up slightly, other countries in the region remain down. Sales in Central Europe and the CIS are expected to remain under pressure. And based on the factors we covered earlier, South America is now projected to increase about 25%.
Turning to another product category. We expect retail sales of turf equipment and compact utility tractors in the U.S. and Canada to be up 5% to 10% in the year. We remain cautiously optimistic for this market as we have witnessed a slow, steady movement in the right direction. Economic indicators are improving. Weather has been favorable for sales, and we have had a very good start to the all-important spring selling season.
Putting this all together on Slide 20. Deere sales for worldwide Ag & Turf are now projected to be up 9% to 11% in the year versus our previous forecast of up 4% to 6%. Currency translation on net sales is projected to be positive about three points.  For the year, the A&T division's operating margin is forecast to be around 12% to 13%.
Let's focus now on Construction & Forestry on Slide 21. With dealers replenishing their fleet and global forestry market strengthening from a very low base, Deere's net sales were up 52% in the quarter. Production tonnage was up 82%. The division reported an operating profit of $36 million due to the very large volume increases from last year's very low base and positive price realization, C&F's incremental margin was about 36%.
On Slide 22, although we are forecasting the U.S. construction industry to be down about 5% for the full year, we feel the market has reached its bottom. We are encouraged by a number of positive development. Independent rental companies are in talks and in some cases beginning to purchase earth-moving equipment. Also, Deere dealers are starting to see an improvement in rental utilization and used-equipment turns. As mentioned earlier, global forestry markets are improving, with pulp prices up significantly from last year and U.S. lumber production increasing. 
On Slide 23, Construction & Forestry sales are now expected to be up 30% in 2010 from the very low levels of 2009. Our previous forecast was up about 21%. Our forecast now has C&F operating margin slightly above break even for the year. Previously, the division had been forecasted to lose money.
Let's move now to our credit operation. Slide 24 shows the worldwide credit operations provision for credit losses as a percent of the total average portfolio. Year-to-date on an annualized basis, the provision is 52 basis points. In the first half of the year, write-offs in the Construction & Forestry portfolio have been considerably lower than expected. We are encouraged by improvement in recovery rate and increased pricing on repossessions. However, we do continue to have high levels of repossessions and delinquent accounts. Consequently, we remain conservative in our forecast provision. The full-year provision for John Deere Credit is forecast to run about 71 basis points, which is an improvement over our prior forecast of about 88 basis points.
On Slide 25, past dues for the worldwide credit operations are about flat with last year. Another promising sign is the C&F revolving charge and financing lease past dues are all lower than a year ago. Annualized write-off continue to reflect the excellent performance of our Ag portfolio, coupled with improvements in the other portfolios. 
Moving to Slide 26. Worldwide credit operations net income attributable to Deere & Co. was $84 million in the quarter versus $68 million last year. The biggest factors were an improvement in financing spreads, a lower provision for credit losses, growth in the portfolio and higher commissions from crop insurance. These were partially offset by lower tax credits related to wind energy projects and higher SA&G.  Looking ahead, we are now projecting worldwide credit operations net income attributable to Deere & Co. of about $300 million in 2010.
Now let's turn our focus back to the equipment operations and take a look at receivables and inventory on Slide 27. For the company as a whole, receivables and inventories were down roughly $900 million in the second quarter versus second quarter 2009. We are now forecasting receivables and inventories to be up about $700 million for the year. The increase of $250 million from our outlook last quarter is a result of increasing production level especially in the fourth quarter.
Now let's discuss the latest on retail sales. On Slide 28, you see the product categories for U.S. and Canada for the month of April expressed in units. For utility tractors, industry sales were down 6%. Deere was down low-double digits. Row-crop tractor industry sales were up 6% and Deere was up less than the industry. 4WD tractor industry sales were up 40%. Deere was up more than the industry. And for combines, the industry was up 21%. Deere was up a single digit. Looking at Deere dealer inventories in the bottom chart, for row-crop tractors, Deere ended April with inventories of 18% of trailing 12-month sales. Combine inventories were at 8% of sales.
Turning to Slide 29. In Western Europe, sales of John Deere tractors were down a single digit and combines were down double digits in April. Deere's retail sales of selected turf and utility equipment in the U.S. and Canada were up several digits in the month. Construction & Forestry sales in the U.S. and Canada, on both a First-in-the-Dirt and settlement basis, were up double digits in the month.
Slide 30 shows raw material and logistics cost down about $70 million in the quarter. We now forecast material cost decreases of approximately $100 million for the year. This is slightly lower than our previous forecast, reflecting higher commodity price projections for inputs like steel. By division, the Ag & Turf savings are forecast at about $125 million. For Construction &  Forestry, we are now forecasting a material cost increase of about $25 million. This is due to the currency impact on partner products and higher steel prices.
Now let's look at a few housekeeping items. Looking at R&D expense on Slide 31, R&D was up about 4% in the quarter with currency translation accounting for about one point. Year-to-date, R&D expense is up about 6%. For the full year, R&D expense is expected to be up about 13%. We expect R&D to ramp up in the second half of the year due to Interim Tier 4 durability build and feasibility testing on products that have Interim Tier 4 production dates after 2011.
Moving now to Slide 32. Pension expense in the second quarter was up about $70 million. The 2010 forecast calls for an increase of about $350 million in pension and OPEB expense, which is down from our previous forecast of about $400 million. Of the $350 million, about $300 million will hit cost of sales, leaving about $50 million in SA&G. Approximately $275 million of the additional expense is attributable to the Ag & Turf division, while the increase for C&F is about $75 million.
On Slide 33, SA&G expense for the equipment operations was up about 8% in the quarter. Variable incentive compensation accounted for about five points and currency translation added about three points.
For fiscal 2010, we now project SA&G to be up about nine points. Variable incentive compensation is expected to contribute about four points of the change as profitability improve. In fiscal 2009, when profitability was lower, variable incentive compensation was about six points lower than it was in 2008. Pension and OPEB accounts were about two points and currency translation about two points.
Moving to the tax rate on Slide 34. The second quarter tax rate includes the charge for U.S. healthcare legislation of about $130 million. For 2010, the full year effective tax rate is expected to be about 40%. This includes the $130 million charge. Excluding the charge, the forecast effective tax rate for 2010 is 34% to 35%.
Before touching on cash flow, currency movements both translation and transaction or trade flows, increased operating profit by about $80 million in the second quarter, predominantly in Ag & Turf.
On Slide 35, you see the strong cash flow from our equipment operations even in the areas of tough market conditions like 2009. This reflects in large part our success managing assets and controlling working capital level. We anticipate strong cash flow from the equipment operations in 2010 about $2.5 billion, up from last year's $1.4 billion. Such strong cash flow is further testament to the successful execution of the SVA [Shareholder Value Added] model.
On Slide 36, capital expenditures are expected to be about $900 million for the year primarily driven by Interim Tier 4. Depreciation and amortization is projected to be about $550 million. Our forecast currently includes about $600 million of pension and OPEB contributions in the year.
In closing, John Deere has reached the halfway mark of 2010 on a strong pace. We're looking forward to delivering a solid second half of the year. Our performance, no doubt, reflects some improvement in overall economic condition. It certainly reflects strong demand for large farm machinery in the United States and other key markets. 
By the same token, we are benefiting from the solid execution of our operating and marketing plan, allowing us to quickly capitalize on this positive move in the marketplace. We've been quite successful extending our competitive position as well, increasing capacity and adding productive new model of equipment to serve an expanding global customer base. As a result, we believe our company is well positioned to benefit from a growing worldwide economy and to continue delivering value to our customers and investors for the long haul. 
Marie?

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Susan. We are now ready to begin the Q&A portion of this call. The operator is going to instruct us on the polling procedure. As usual, however, I ask that you respect to the rest of the audience, participants, and ask two questions, a limit of
componenttext:
Thank you, Susan. We are now ready to begin the Q&A portion of this call. The operator is going to instruct us on the polling procedure. As usual, however, I ask that you respect to the rest of the audience, participants, and ask two questions, a limit of two question. No follow ups in that limit. If you have additional questions, you are of course, welcome to get back into the queue. 
Laura, we're ready.

componenttext: Let me ask in Brazil then for the second one. Your share has been very good in the past couple of years. It was a little less good in the past three, four months on high-horsepower tractors, what I'm talking about. I know that's lumpy. But has there been any production issues? componenttext: There have not been any production issues, but you are correct that we are in the process of a transition. I don't have the exact dates on the individual models, and a couple actually come in from other markets. But Rob, as you well know, you need to look at market show over a long period of time. You have normal ebbs and flows, and we feel very good about the positioning of our product line especially now that we have these new products available.

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Marie, can you please talk about the drivers of the production ramp in your international ag facilities? How much of that is to support the transition to Tier 4 Interim versus stronger production for North America, Brazil and Russia?
componenttext: Marie, can you please talk about the drivers of the production ramp in your international ag facilities? How much of that is to support the transition to Tier 4 Interim versus stronger production for North America, Brazil and Russia?

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our international factories in terms of producing for the U.S., there would be some with the medium-sized tractors in particular. They're coming from markets like Mexico and Mannheim. So there would be connectivity there. Most of those products though, I
componenttext: Our international factories in terms of producing for the U.S., there would be some with the medium-sized tractors in particular. They're coming from markets like Mexico and Mannheim. So there would be connectivity there. Most of those products though, I think virtually all, would not be subject to IT 4 requirements until starting in 2012 because of the horsepower breaks. And if you recall, the IT 4 breaks at 175 for 2011 and then below 175 in 2012.

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: My question relates to the guidance. The first half of the year, you had sales of $10.8 billion. In the second half, your guidance is at $12.6 billion. You've got $1.8 billion of sales growth, sequentially, I'm talking. And on the segment profits, the fir
componenttext: My question relates to the guidance. The first half of the year, you had sales of $10.8 billion. In the second half, your guidance is at $12.6 billion. You've got $1.8 billion of sales growth, sequentially, I'm talking. And on the segment profits, the first half, you did about $1.3 billion. The back half guidance roughly implies $1.2 billion. So again, we're saying sales we're going up $1.8 billion sequentially, but profits go down $100 million. Now I can see the R&D, first half to second half does go up 100. You get a little D&A help, a little pension help. But let's call that 100, I understand the 1.3 going to 1.2. But on the revenue growth of $1.8 billion, if I think of a typical incremental margin of 25% that you would get, that you're saying we're not going to get at all. Sequentially, not year-over-year, sequentially, that's implying your price versus cost in the back half of the year is like negative 3%.

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our raw materials in the back half of the year are expected to be a negative of approximately $170 million. That's what's implied in the guidance in those final six months.
componenttext: Our raw materials in the back half of the year are expected to be a negative of approximately $170 million. That's what's implied in the guidance in those final six months.

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, that's year-over-year though. I'm talking sequentially, do we think price versus cost is at negative?
componenttext: Well, that's year-over-year though. I'm talking sequentially, do we think price versus cost is at negative?

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Because we've had favorable raw materials cost in both the first and the second quarters. We had two points of positive price realization in both for the company in both the first and second quarters in our guidance, David, which as Susan pointed out
componenttext: Yes. Because we've had favorable raw materials cost in both the first and the second quarters. We had two points of positive price realization in both for the company in both the first and second quarters in our guidance, David, which as Susan pointed out, is unchanged. We're looking at for the full year about 1.5, and that implies you'll be a little less in the second half of the year. You have higher SA&G as we move into the back half of the year too.

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
