componenttext: Quick question on the outlook and then cash flow. On the availability that you talked about for Series 9000 (sic) [9000 Series] tractors, are there any initiatives being pursued to increase capacity for this fiscal year? Or should we assume it's pretty much steady as she goes?

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have been increasing our capabilities of reaching, of helping our capabilities of delivering products to customers over the course of the year. We've increased our schedule as your -- undoubtedly we have several times. We had undertaken a capacity incr
componenttext: We have been increasing our capabilities of reaching, of helping our capabilities of delivering products to customers over the course of the year. We've increased our schedule as your -- undoubtedly we have several times. We had undertaken a capacity increase starting in 2008 and are benefiting certainly from the actions taken there, on both combines and large tractors. Availability of the 9000, specifically is September. And for 8's [8R Series] availability, I should say effective availability in both cases, effective availability is November.

componenttext: Basically, we've got -- it's intercompany money, temporarily loan capital corporation. It's as simple as that.

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Henry Kirn. [UBS]
componenttext: Our next question comes from Henry Kirn. [UBS]

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Wondering if you could chat about why the FX in the guidance didn't change by very much, given the move in the euro?
componenttext: Wondering if you could chat about why the FX in the guidance didn't change by very much, given the move in the euro?

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our forecasting process, we would do our valuation of our forecast at the end of April. And we would have used the average rate for currencies that was in effect at the end of April to translate the income statement and balance sheet for 31 October 2010,
componenttext: Our forecasting process, we would do our valuation of our forecast at the end of April. And we would have used the average rate for currencies that was in effect at the end of April to translate the income statement and balance sheet for 31 October 2010, and then for the income for the remaining period of May through October. We have done some sensitivity analysis in terms of what -- and I'll talk specifically about the euro, what a change in the euro might mean. If at the time we did the translation, we were looking at about an average of 1.34 for the euro. If the euro goes between 1.27 and 1.15, you're looking at a favorable impact. We estimate, all other things equal, remember, they never are, but all other things equal, a favorable operating profit benefits the Ag & Turf division of somewhere between -- and precisely, it's says seven and 22. And of course, it never looked exactly that way. So you can see a little bit of the sensitivity actually does not work to harm us in this particular case.

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: So I might just add to that. In general, our trade flows relative to the euro land or euro zone versus the United States are relatively well balanced. And to the extent that we've had the euro being an issue relative to our financials, good or bad, it gen
componenttext: So I might just add to that. In general, our trade flows relative to the euro land or euro zone versus the United States are relatively well balanced. And to the extent that we've had the euro being an issue relative to our financials, good or bad, it generally happens when there is steep, sharp movements in the euro versus the dollar. And so the analysis that Marie has shared with you shows that in general, we're fairly well balanced relative to the euro. And that's why you see this basically de minimis impact from the movement going forward. Now Marie made a very important caveat that is, all other things being equal, and of course, they never are, but that would be our estimate today.

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010

componenttext: Have you seen any change in behavior from buyers in the European countries with sovereign debt issues?

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's a fair question. Actually, Henry, the market conditions there and the farmer buying mood is very poor. And so we haven't seen any cancellations, if that's what you're asking, but things are at a very low level of activity. So we haven't seen things
componenttext: That's a fair question. Actually, Henry, the market conditions there and the farmer buying mood is very poor. And so we haven't seen any cancellations, if that's what you're asking, but things are at a very low level of activity. So we haven't seen things deteriorate further. In fact, if you want to find any silver lining, they are indicating some stabilization again at a pretty low level.

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: We continue to see very good levels of activity in our Ag business, specifically in places like Brazil and from large equipments in the U.S., and actually a bit of a turn in the Turf business and even in medium-sized tractors. So we saw some other categor
componenttext: We continue to see very good levels of activity in our Ag business, specifically in places like Brazil and from large equipments in the U.S., and actually a bit of a turn in the Turf business and even in medium-sized tractors. So we saw some other categories starting to improve. And then the Construction business is seeing a little bit more, as our dealers are starting to see a little bit of field activity, it seems business is starting to stabilize a little more confidence.

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: So let me just jump in on -- a short answer to that, Alex, would be pretty much everything has gotten better at the macro level. A&T is up, C&S up and the Credit Operations (sic) [Credit & Operations] are up. And then on top of that, we're seeing a very f
componenttext: So let me just jump in on -- a short answer to that, Alex, would be pretty much everything has gotten better at the macro level. A&T is up, C&S up and the Credit Operations (sic) [Credit & Operations] are up. And then on top of that, we're seeing a very favorable mix. We've seen favorable mix development inside of A&T, further favorable mix development.

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions on the Construction & Forestry side of the business. Could you walk through some of the assumptions around this business? I know in the last quarter, you were talking about inventories flat. It sounds at this point like you're lookin
componenttext: A couple of questions on the Construction & Forestry side of the business. Could you walk through some of the assumptions around this business? I know in the last quarter, you were talking about inventories flat. It sounds at this point like you're looking at some inventory build on the part of dealers and then retail sales down 5% to 10%. So can you just update those?

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Retail sales for the industry, we think will now be down about 5%. And we think that's frankly behind us. We think that we're approaching a bottoming, if we're not already there. We've actually started to see, and I want to be careful because this i
componenttext: Sure. Retail sales for the industry, we think will now be down about 5%. And we think that's frankly behind us. We think that we're approaching a bottoming, if we're not already there. We've actually started to see, and I want to be careful because this is from very low levels of activity, but we've actually started to see a little bit of activity out of rental and it's in smaller equipment, but again, all, remember, very low levels.

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the second part of it was on the inventory side.
componenttext: And the second part of it was on the inventory side.

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010

componenttext: The other part was, we have more production now planned in our fourth quarter than we did when we last gave guidance. And so that really drives the increase in inventories and receivables. Some of that's company-owned, a little bit of it's in the field.

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010

componenttext: And then could you talk a little bit about the lead times that you're seeing from your suppliers? And then the lead times to dealers in the categories, where you are starting to see the increase on the  Construction & Forestry side?

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of availability, actually, we're doing extremely well with our suppliers and have worked pretty hard with them. And they have worked hard to help meet our needs. And we actually had some various strategies to flex up and down. That's actually a p
componenttext: In terms of availability, actually, we're doing extremely well with our suppliers and have worked pretty hard with them. And they have worked hard to help meet our needs. And we actually had some various strategies to flex up and down. That's actually a part of our normal routine business, planning process. The order fulfillment process in the Construction Equipment divisions are working fine. We have plenty of ability to respond, but I don't have a definitive number for you on lead times. But again, things are starting to turn, and we're doing a very good job at meeting customer needs.

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: To the question, it's actually Construction Equipment area. Do you have any sense how much of the improvement that you're seeing in your high production is going to its inventory restocking or rebounding of the fleets of your dealers so as opposed to pure
componenttext: To the question, it's actually Construction Equipment area. Do you have any sense how much of the improvement that you're seeing in your high production is going to its inventory restocking or rebounding of the fleets of your dealers so as opposed to pure end demand? I assume that you're sort of suggesting that with end demand not going anywhere, and almost all the buying is replenished on the fleet. Then you expect that to be finished this year in fiscal 2010?

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I know I wouldn't say it would be finished, because you added such a low level of activity and frankly, even in terms of the field inventory. You are seeing, again from the rental companies, a little bit of a turn and in -- but most of it is fleet, either
componenttext: I know I wouldn't say it would be finished, because you added such a low level of activity and frankly, even in terms of the field inventory. You are seeing, again from the rental companies, a little bit of a turn and in -- but most of it is fleet, either it is some replenishment on the part of our dealers.

componenttext: And then second, do you expect -- do you have any feel for where your inventories will wind up at the end of the year? I assume, which is based on projection with you seeing demand, you're still supposed to have very tight farm inventories at the end of the year in the farm sector?

componenttext: That would be true. That's in part by design and then certainly in response to a very good market condition.

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Seth Weber. [RBC]
componenttext: Our next question comes from Seth Weber. [RBC]

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your comment about the used equipment inventories in Europe, is that across product lines? And is that more just an industry commentary? Do your dealers -- can you just give us some color there?
componenttext: Your comment about the used equipment inventories in Europe, is that across product lines? And is that more just an industry commentary? Do your dealers -- can you just give us some color there?

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: That is more or less across the line. Of course, we're over-represented by tractors and combines in Western Europe. And we do not believe that Deere is unique in this regard. And in fact, we would tell you that our inventories in general are as in good a
componenttext: That is more or less across the line. Of course, we're over-represented by tractors and combines in Western Europe. And we do not believe that Deere is unique in this regard. And in fact, we would tell you that our inventories in general are as in good a shape as most anybody's. And this backup of the used goods is really -- tends to be more of an industry-wide issue in Europe.

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then flipping over to Brazil, I mean, you raised your forecast for the South American market. Do you expect revenue comps to be down year-over-year for the second half, just given the timing of some of the programs that were in place last year? Or do
componenttext: And then flipping over to Brazil, I mean, you raised your forecast for the South American market. Do you expect revenue comps to be down year-over-year for the second half, just given the timing of some of the programs that were in place last year? Or do you think that, that's...

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, Seth, I'm glad you brought that up. You may not be aware, and we didn't mention that overtly in the call. The Brazilian government has announced an extension or continuation of the low rate financing under the FINAME program. It is currently 4.5
componenttext: Actually, Seth, I'm glad you brought that up. You may not be aware, and we didn't mention that overtly in the call. The Brazilian government has announced an extension or continuation of the low rate financing under the FINAME program. It is currently 4.5%, and it ends at the end of June. There is another rate that will be effective from the 1st of July to the 31st of December. And that is 5.5%, which is up a little bit from 4.5%, but still in very attractive level in the market. Regarding the Mais Alimentos program, at least as far as last week, we still had not have heard anything from the government as to whether or not it would be continued conventional wisdom in Brazil, does believe it will be continued. So I wouldn't see a decline in the fourth quarter. We had originally talked about that when we assume that the FINAME rates went back to more normal levels. As we look forward into 2011, again absent any other information, you have to assume that, that special FINAME rate will end at the end of December. At least, that's what for planning purposes what you would expect. It will affect sales though a little bit further into our fiscal 2011, because you usually have to commit with the bank sometime. We expect it would be by the end of November. And then you have a few months after that to actually take delivery on the equipment. So that would get us into sometime into our second quarter. That's a long-winded answer.

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Barry Bannister. [Stifel, Nicolaus & Co.]
componenttext: Our next question comes from Barry Bannister. [Stifel, Nicolaus & Co.]

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Now that the dust has settled, I wanted to step back and ask a bigger picture question. And Deere as a whole and lately in Construction & Forestry, this obsession with working capital has caused some pretty extraordinary swings in production tonnage and o
componenttext: Now that the dust has settled, I wanted to step back and ask a bigger picture question. And Deere as a whole and lately in Construction & Forestry, this obsession with working capital has caused some pretty extraordinary swings in production tonnage and operating leverage. And it's resulted in volatility of operating earnings, with EPS down 40% in '09 and then back up 42% in '10. So what I'm getting from investors is that they really view Deere as more of a short-term speculative vehicle and not so much a long-term investment. And the incentive system inside Deere is SVA-based, has a very sharp focus on capital employed. So we can expect these huge swings in production schedules on a regular basis going forward. So I guess my question is, do we have a situation here of misaligned interests? And would it be better to smooth earnings a little bit over the cycles by ultimately over and underproducing over time, better than panicking, cutting production and quickly raising production when we find ourselves short competitively of inventory? Do you have any thoughts on that?

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I certainly do. We would tell you that our SVA model has been extremely powerful in raising the overall returns that we have generated as a company. You may recall that we traditionally turned our assets maybe once, a little more than 1x, well over 2x. We
componenttext: I certainly do. We would tell you that our SVA model has been extremely powerful in raising the overall returns that we have generated as a company. You may recall that we traditionally turned our assets maybe once, a little more than 1x, well over 2x. We think that's helpful to our customers because they get new, fresh product that is specifically designed to meet their needs, as opposed to taking inventories that has been sitting out sometimes for, frankly, too long at the dealer. And it's not optioned the way the customer wants it. In terms of our ability to manage working capital, you're not mentioning the very powerful effect that it has had on our ability to generate cash flow. And we think that is critical. Actually, we get very solid feedback on this. With the market turns down, Barry, eventually you're going to have to react. And it's a question of timing, whether you do it today or tomorrow. We do not think our -- we have been knee-jerk at all in responding to market conditions. And again, I think that our very superior return speak for themselves.

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Does your $4 EPS guidance in 2010 include any loss for the sale of windmills?
componenttext: Does your $4 EPS guidance in 2010 include any loss for the sale of windmills?

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have not arrived at any sort of definitive course of action relative to the Wind business. And as a result, our forecast does not contemplate any sort of definitive action one way or the other, other than that it continues to be in the portfolio. What
componenttext: We have not arrived at any sort of definitive course of action relative to the Wind business. And as a result, our forecast does not contemplate any sort of definitive action one way or the other, other than that it continues to be in the portfolio. What we've announced is that we've undertaken a strategic review. And at the right time, we will reveal what the result of that review contemplate. But right now, our forecast contemplates that wind is continuing a piece of the John Deere portfolio. I would go back to the previous question, Barry. And just also offering a point, that 2009 was an extraordinary year in terms of the scheduled reductions that were put in place and then the reactions. And one that I would say, obviously, if you're going to develop any sort of hypothesis, I think it needs to be taken with a grain of salt, and that it was so extraordinary. And we are firmly of the opinion that long term, that being very, very quick to react in terms of schedule, making sure that we have the right product out there at the right time, with the right optionality so we don't have to give it away is, in fact, in the long-term best interest of our shareholders. And it's a very complicated subject that we'd be very willing to discuss with you further.

componenttext: And then for your cash flow outlook, cash flow operations, can you explain something to me? Maybe I'm just doing my math wrong. But you're forecasting that to increase by $600 million, pretty healthy. But net income in your guidance is up a little over $400 million, when you add back that charge. And then your receivables and inventories are actually going up as well, so I'm presuming working capital would be more of a use than previously expected. And your depreciation actually is going down a little bit. So what am I missing that contributes an incremental $200 million or more to cash flow from operations?

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010

componenttext: Well, with the rise in payables, with the rise in activity late in the fourth quarter, you get a little bit unfavorables. And then we've got dividends from the financial services that we didn't have last year. And I think those are the two biggest.

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, the dividends by itself, I think, is $200 million a year ago, because we were relevering the balance sheet of the capital corporation. We didn't take any money out of the financial services. So effectively, the earnings were not monetized. Whereas th
componenttext: Yes, the dividends by itself, I think, is $200 million a year ago, because we were relevering the balance sheet of the capital corporation. We didn't take any money out of the financial services. So effectively, the earnings were not monetized. Whereas this year, at least 2/3 of the earnings will be monetized in terms of cash and the equipment operations.

componenttext: For example, in the payables, last year, our incentive compensation accruals would have been down significant. I think we made a comment that -- or a year ago, that six points of the SA&G decline was because of the reduction in the incentive compensation expense. So that's a reduction and an accrual which, through the cash flow statement, effectively because it shows up almost as a use of cash. And then as that accrual is being rebuilt, that's a noncash charge to earnings, and so it's those sorts of items.

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: One, I'm curious on your R&D and SG&A expense. When we think about each quarter, we've raised that expense. Your percentage increased a couple of points relative to where we were when we first started off, yet we've underspent in the first half. So why th
componenttext: One, I'm curious on your R&D and SG&A expense. When we think about each quarter, we've raised that expense. Your percentage increased a couple of points relative to where we were when we first started off, yet we've underspent in the first half. So why that's going higher or how we think about the impact on Q3 relative to Q4? I'm trying to think if there's anything else going on there? Or is that cushioned in the guidance? And then my last question, just on your 2011 farm cash receipts forecast, again, another stellar year. It's probably the second best year in U.S. farmer history. Under what scenario would 2011 sales be down in the U.S., just based on your cash receipt forecast. Am I missing something why it's not going to be up, I guess?

headline: Deere & Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me go back into the R&D first. We have no deliberate cushioning in either R&D or SA&G. The expenses required to meet IT 4 are real, and that engineering will be ramping up as we move through time, does it get all the way up to 13%? I can't guarantee i
componenttext: Let me go back into the R&D first. We have no deliberate cushioning in either R&D or SA&G. The expenses required to meet IT 4 are real, and that engineering will be ramping up as we move through time, does it get all the way up to 13%? I can't guarantee it, but that is a very real cost and we've got plans in place for that. SA&G, they will be some launch expenses. And I think there is -- as you know, we weren't sure how the year would progress. I think there might have been a few things in SA&G that might have been postponed into the second half of the year that we had some flexibility on. I know even in my own case, some training, I didn't do in the first half, I may do in the second.

componenttextpreview: At this stage of the game, we don't have guidance for 2011. So it's very, very difficult to predict. The factors that you're looking at seem to be very good. We would hope there would be some upside coming, as you see recovery in livestock and from the Tu
componenttext:
At this stage of the game, we don't have guidance for 2011. So it's very, very difficult to predict. The factors that you're looking at seem to be very good. We would hope there would be some upside coming, as you see recovery in livestock and from the Turf & Utility as well. But we do not have a forecast, so I'm unable to give you a better answer.
Thank you all for participating in the call today. And of course, as usual, we'll be able to answer your questions throughout the day. Goodbye.
