headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Deere Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Ms. Marie Ziegler, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Deere Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Ms. Marie Ziegler, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Also on the call today are Jim Field, our Chief Financial Officer; as well as Susan Karlix; and Justin Merrimac, from the Deere Investor Relations staff. This morning, we'll take a closer look at Deere's third quarter earnings, and then, s
componenttext:
Good morning. Also on the call today are Jim Field, our Chief Financial Officer; as well as Susan Karlix; and Justin Merrimac, from the Deere Investor Relations staff. 
This morning, we'll take a closer look at Deere's third quarter earnings, and then, spend some time talking about our markets and how we see the last quarter of our fiscal year shaping up. After that, we'll respond to your questions. Please note that slides are available to complement the call this morning and can be accessed on our website at www.johndeere.com.
First as usual, a reminder. This call is being broadcast live on the Internet and recorded for future transmission and use by Deere and Thomson Reuters. Any other use, recording or transmission of any portion of this copyrighted broadcast without the express written consent of Deere is strictly prohibited. Participants in the call, including the Q&A session, agree that their likeness and remarks in all media may be stored and used as part of the earnings call.
This call includes forward-looking comments concerning the company's projections, plans and objectives for the future that are subject to important risks and uncertainties. Actual results might differ materially from those projected in these forward-looking statements. Additional information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ materially is contained in the company's most recent Form 8-K and periodic reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
The company, except as required by law, undertakes no obligation to update or revise its forward-looking information. The call and accompanying materials are not an offer to sell or a solicitation of offers to buy any of the company's securities. 
This call may also include financial measures that are not in conformance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America, otherwise, known as GAAP. Additional information concerning these measures, including reconciliations to comparable GAAP measures, is posted on our website at www.johndeere.com/financialreports under Other Financial Information. Call participants should consider the other information on risks and uncertainties and non-GAAP measures in addition to the information presented on today's call.
And now, for a closer look at our third quarter, here's Susan.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Marie. John Deere's strong performance continued in the third quarter of 2010. Income was up 47% on a sales increase of 18%. Earnings were the highest for any third quarter in the company's history and sales were the second-highest. The gain wa
componenttext:
Thank you, Marie. John Deere's strong performance continued in the third quarter of 2010. Income was up 47% on a sales increase of 18%. Earnings were the highest for any third quarter in the company's history and sales were the second-highest. The gain was led by Ag & Turf, which had another blockbuster quarter. 
Construction & Forestry had its highest profits in seven quarters and our Credit Operations had another solid performance. The company is being helped by somewhat improved business conditions, but tailwinds are only part of the story. After all, construction markets are still weak by historical standards and some Ag markets, such as Europe and the CIS, remain under pressure.
What our results clearly show is the disciplined execution of our business plan and our focus on serving customers with advanced products and services. This has allowed us to fully capitalize on the current market conditions. 
Now let's look at the quarter in more detail, starting with Slide 3. Net sales and revenues were up 16% to $6.8 billion in the quarter. Net income attributable to Deere & Co. was $617 million, and as just, mentioned up 47% compared with the third quarter last year and our highest-ever income for the third quarter.
Turning to Slide 4. Total worldwide equipment operations net sales were up 18% to $6.2 billion. Currency translation on net sales was flat versus our May forecast for currency to be up about two points in the third quarter.  Price realization in the quarter was positive by two points.
On Slide 5, worldwide production tonnage was up 31% in the quarter. This slide illustrates that, with one exception, tonnage in each SBU and region was up in line with the forecast provided a quarter ago. The exception was outside the U.S. and Canada, where tonnage came in lower than anticipated due to continued weakness in Western Europe. For the full year, worldwide production tonnage is now forecast to be up about 14%.  
Let's turn to the company outlook on Slide 6. Fourth quarter sales are expected to be up approximately 32% compared with the fourth quarter of 2009. Currency translation on net sales is expected to be negative by about one point. Net income attributable to Deere & Co. is forecast to be approximately $375 million in the fourth quarter. For the full year, net equipment sales are forecast to be up about 12% compared with fiscal year 2009. This includes about two points of positive currency translation and approximately two points of positive price realization.
Turning to review of our individual businesses. Let's start with Agriculture & Turf on Slide 7. Production tonnage was up 24% in the quarter on a 12% increase in sales. Operating profit, however, jumped by nearly $345 million or 72% to $824 million. The increase was primarily due to higher shipment and production volume and improved price realization, partially offset by higher post-retirement benefit cost. As you can see, margins were impressive. The division had an operating margin of approximately 16% in the quarter and an incremental margin of about 61%. 
Before we review the sales outlook, let's look at some of the fundamentals affecting the Ag business, starting on Slide 8. On the heels of the recent commodity price increases, the outlook for most crop prices is up considerably for the 2010/'11 crop year. Corn prices are being helped by increasing global demand and have moved in sympathy with the poor-trading crops in many areas of the world. We project that 2009/2010 stock in the U.S. and Canada will end 250 million bushels below a year ago and fall another 150 million bushels in the coming year.
Soybean exports have remained strong. Growing level consumption is expected to keep soybean prices at extremely favorable levels for the '10/'11 crop. Global wheat stocks have tightened with lower winter wheat planting as well as yield losses in Western Europe, and to an even greater extent, in the CIS.
2010/'11 cotton prices remain well above the '08/'09 level, driven by the recovery in global demand and a reduction in the global cotton supply.
Turning to Slide 9. 2010 U.S. farm cash receipts are now forecast to be up about 6% from 2009 to about $317 billion. That's about $4 billion higher than our last forecast, and is driven by increased crop receipts. 2011 farm cash receipts are forecast to be slightly above the 2010 level.
Deere's outlook for the EU-27 is shown on Slide 10. The recent upward movement in grain prices might seem at odds with our rather subdued 2010 industry sales outlook for Western Europe. No doubt, some customers are locking in crop sales at attractive prices, which should provide support for 2011. That said, industry sales of new goods have been weak this year, particularly in combines. While European farmer sentiment is slowly improving, the dairy and livestock sector is still reeling from losses of prior years. Throughout, has hurt yields or customers in many areas and used equipment inventories remain at high levels.
Slide 11 illustrates the extreme heat and drought conditions in Russia and Eastern Europe. These conditions have sparked wildfires, and the picture on the right depicts some of the smoke from those fires visible from our Domodedovo facility outside Moscow. 
Last week, the USDA estimated the 2010/'11 FSU-12 wheat production would be down about 23%. Some industry observers believe the losses could go even higher. Although Russia is reporting success controlling the fires, the consequence of a severe drought and its impact on global grain markets won't be fully known for some time.
Farm net income in Brazil and Argentina is on Slide 12. We continue to see good farm income from soybeans and sugarcane, the two crops that drive the bulk of equipment purchases in Brazil.
Other positive factors include strong global demand for Brazilian commodities, a 5% to 10% decrease in input cost and strong government-sponsored low-rate finance programs that run through at least the end of calendar year 2010. These all contribute to positive-producer attitude, which translate into higher spending on farm equipment.
We have increased our forecast for 2010 farm net income in Argentina. With milk and beef prices high, we continue to see increased demand for tractors, combines, sprayers and forage equipment. Although too early to predict, we are closely monitoring the development of a La Nia weather pattern that could result in lower production and yields in 2011.
Slide 13 highlights the latest additions to our tractor lineup in India. In June, we introduced the 5036C and 5041B (sic) [5041C] tractor models. These tractors were designed and developed in India, with features tailored to the India market.
These 35- and 41-horsepower tractors joined the recently introduced 5038 D, expanding our presence in the targeted 31- to 40-horsepower market. This Horsepower segment makes up almost 50% of the tractor industry in India.
Our 2010 industry outlooks are on Slide 14. Sales of agricultural equipment in the U.S. and Canada are forecast to be at 5% to 10%. We continue to see strength in our order books and have Early Order Programs in place for our seasonal equipment. Although very early, the combine Early Order Program is progressing well and as planned. In absolute numbers, orders are well ahead of last year. 
In the Sprayer, Planter and Tillage Equipment programs, we are seeing strong results very similar to last year. Demand for large tractors has been strong as well. The 8R series tractor introduced last year has been very well-received and we've continued to add schedules throughout the year. 
We are just now introducing the Interim Tier 4 compliance 8R to our dealers and are encouraged by the initial orders of over 1,000 units, well over half of retail sold, with customer names on the order. Effective availability for 8R series tractors is February 2011. Effective availability for our 4WD tractors is November 2010.
Earlier, we touched on the conditions in Western Europe. While fundamentals are promising as we enter 2011, current market conditions are weak, and we are therefore, lowering our industry forecast. We now expect Ag sales to be down 15% to 20% in the year. Sales in Central Europe and the CIS are expected to remain under pressure. And based on the factors we covered earlier, we are increasing our industry forecast for South America to up 25% to 30%.
Turning to another product category. We expect retail sales of Turf and Utility equipment in the U.S. and Canada to be up 10% of 15% in 2010 from the very low levels of a year ago. We have seen an uptick in the commercial milling, riding lawn equipment and golf markets. However, with general economic conditions still uncertain, our optimism for this segment remains tempered with caution.
Putting these all together on Slide 15, Deere sales for worldwide Ag & Turf are now projected to be up 8% in the year. Currency translation on net sales is projected to be positive, about two points. For the year, the A&T division's operating margin is forecast to be around 13%.
The division continued to benefit from strong sales of large Ag equipment in the United States and Canada, with relatively weak sales in the Turf and Utility segment. In May's call, we said favorable mix added one point of margin to Ag & Turf's second quarter results. Now with our new forecast, for the full year, this favorable mix is expected to add about two points to the division's margin in relation to its typical year.
Let's focus now on construction and forestry on Slide 16. Deere's net sales were up 59% in the quarter, while production tonnage nearly doubled, being up 96%. The division reported operating profit of $66 million.
On Slide 17, although we are forecasting the U.S. construction industry to be down about 2% for the full year, we believe the market has reached its bottom. The business is experiencing a slow improvement. We are encouraged by the activity we have seen with independent rental companies and in the Highway Construction segment. Also encouraging, Deere dealers continue to see an improvement in rental utilization and used equipment turns. Still, we remain cautious. 
Uncertainty over the economic recovery persists, and we have lowered our outlook for 2011 housing starts. Meanwhile, global forestry markets are up significantly from the very low levels of last year, and our factories have responded quickly to the increased demand. We are now forecasting Construction Forestry sales to dealers to be up about 35% in 2010 from the very low levels of 2009. The division's full year operating margin is forecast to be in the low single digits.
Let's move now to our Credit Operations. Slide 18 shows the worldwide Credit Operations provision for credit losses as a percent of the total average owned portfolio. Year-to-date, on an annualized basis, the provision is 49 basis points. Write-offs in the Construction and Forestry portfolios continue to improve. Recovery rates are improving steadily. We are seeing fewer repossessions and increased pricing from the repossessions that are occurring, about 9% to 10% since last fall.
The full year provision for John Deere Credit is forecast to runaround 55 basis points, an improvement over our prior forecast of about 71 basis points.
On Slide 19, past dues for the worldwide Credit Operations are lower than last year, with Construction & Forestry being the main driver of improvement. Annualized write-offs reflect a significant improvement in C&S losses.
Moving to Slide 20. Worldwide Credit Operations' net income attributable to Deere & Co. was $95 million in the quarter versus $99 million last year. The biggest factors were an improvement in financing strength and a lower provision for credit losses. These were partially offset by lower tax credits related to wind energy projects. Looking ahead, we are now projecting worldwide Credit Operations net income attributable to Deere & Co. of about $325 million in 2010.
Now let's turn our focus back to the Equipment Operations and take a look at receivables and inventories on Slide 21.  For the company as a whole, receivables and inventories were up roughly $450 million in the third quarter versus third quarter 2009.
Keep in mind, we ended fiscal 2009 with receivables and inventories at rock-bottom levels. In fact, they were $1.3 billion lower than at the end of fiscal 2008. For fiscal year 2010, we are now forecasting receivables and inventories to be up about $950 million. This reflects higher production volumes in the fourth quarter versus the very low volumes in the fourth quarter last year.
These higher production volumes are intended in part to facilitate the transition to Interim Tier 4. They also reflect higher demand in the Construction & Forestry division and some Ag & Turf markets.
Now let's discuss the latest on retail sales. Slide 22 presents the product category detail in the U.S. and Canada for the month of July expressed in units. Utility tractor industry sales were up 3%. Deere sales were up several digits. Row-crop industry tractor sales were down 10%. Deere was down in line with the industry. 4WD industry sales were down 2%. Deere was down double digits. Combine industry sales were down 7% and Deere was down slightly less than the industry.
Looking at Deere dealer inventories in the bottom chart. For row-crop tractors, Deere ended July, with inventories at 18% of trailing 12 months sales. Combine inventories were at 19% of sales.
Turning to Slide 23. In Western Europe, sales of John Deere tractors were up double digits and combines were down double digits in July. Deere's retail sales of selected Turf & Utility equipment in the U.S. and Canada were up a single digit in the month. Construction & Forestry sales in the U.S. and Canada on both a First-in-the-Dirt and Settlement basis were up double digits for the month.
Slide 24 shows raw material and logistics cost up about $10 million in the quarter. We now forecast material cost decreases of approximately $150 million for the year. By division, the Ag & Turf savings are forecast at about $175 million. For Construction & Forestry, we continue to forecast a material cost increase of about $25 million. This is due to the currency impact on partner products and higher steel prices.
While this forecast is an improvement over last quarter, remember that prices for many commodities have been moving up recently and our cost increases, typically lag the commodity market by three to six months.
Now let's look at a few housekeeping items. Looking at R&D expense on Slide 25, R&D was up about 5% in the third quarter with currency translation accounting for negative approximately two points. Year-to-date, R&D expense is up about 6%. For the full year, R&D expense is expected to be up about 10%. We expect R&D spending to increase in the fourth quarter as we approach significant product launches with Interim Tier 4 engines and remain at high levels over the next three years as we approach the Final Tier 4 admission standards.
Moving now to Slide 26. Pension and OPEB expense in the third quarter was up about $100 million. The 2010 forecast calls for an increase of about $350 million in pension and OPEB expense, unchanged from our previous forecast. We have had a slight change in the split between cost of sales and SA&G. Of the $350 million, about $275 million will hit cost of sales with about $75 million now in SA&G. Approximately $275 million of the additional expenses is attributable to the Ag & Turf division, while the increase in C&F is about $75 million.
On Slide 27, SA&G expense for the equipment operations was up about 17% in the quarter. Variable incentive compensation accounted for about eight points, and currency translation added about three points. For fiscal 2010, we project SA&G to be up about nine points, unchanged from our previous forecast. 
Variable incentive compensation is expected to account for about five points of the change as the company's performance has contributed -- improved. Pension and OPEB accounts were about two points and currency translation, about one point.
Moving to the income tax rate on Slide 28. The third quarter effective tax rate for the equipment operations was about 34%. The full year 2010 effective tax rate is expected to be about 40%. That includes the tax expense of about $130 million related to U.S. healthcare legislation recognized in the second quarter. Excluding the charge, the forecast of effective tax rate for 2010 would be about 34%.
Before touching on cash flow, the combined effect of translation and transaction, or trade flows, increased operating profit by about $60 million in the third quarter, primarily in Ag & Turf.
On Slide 29, you see the strong cash flow from our equipment operations even in years of tough market conditions, like last year. This reflects, in large part, our success managing assets and controlling working capital levels. We anticipate cash flow from equipment operations of about $2.4 billion for the year, a $1 billion increase over 2009. Such strong cash flow is further testament to our successful execution of the SDA model.
As you can see on Slide 30, in accordance with our stated use of cash priority, we resume share repurchase in the quarter, buying back some 1.7 million shares. As we generate good cash flow, share repurchases will continue to be an avenue we consider when accessing our use of cash.
Turning to Slide 31. Capital expenditures are expected to be about $850 million for the year, primarily driven by the Interim Tier 4 emissions rule. Depreciation and amortization is projected to be about $550 million. Our forecast currently includes about $700 million of pension and OPEB contributions in the year.
In closing, John Deere enters the last quarter of 2010 on a strong pace. Our performance reflects somewhat more positive economic conditions and strong demand for large farm machinery, particularly in the United States. At the same time, John Deere remains focused on serving a growing global customer base, steadily increasing capacity, adding productive new models of equipment and successfully extending our competitive position throughout the world. As a result, we believe the company is exceptionally well-positioned to benefit from a growing economy and to help meet the world's increasing need for food, feed, fuel, shelter and infrastructure well into the future. Marie?

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Susan. We are now ready to begin the Q&A portion of this call. [Operator Instructions] Operator?
componenttext: Thank you, Susan. We are now ready to begin the Q&A portion of this call. [Operator Instructions] Operator?

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Ann Duignan. [JPMorgan]
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Ann Duignan. [JPMorgan]

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: My first question is on the near term and your fourth quarter outlook, particularly on the Ag & Turf side, you noted that margins would be about 13%. That would imply much lower margin in Q4 than I had been forecasting, and much lower than Q3. Marie, I th
componenttext: My first question is on the near term and your fourth quarter outlook, particularly on the Ag & Turf side, you noted that margins would be about 13%. That would imply much lower margin in Q4 than I had been forecasting, and much lower than Q3. Marie, I think you guys addressed it in the call, but I just want to make sure. Are you anticipating a significant hit on gross margins because of the buildup of pre-Tier 4 Interim (sic) [pre-Interim Tier 4] engines? Is that what maybe I was missing in my forecast?

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not directly, Ann. In fact, instead of just addressing Ag & Turf, let me look at it for the full company in relation to our full guidance, and just give you some of the numbers that are in implicit in our guidance. With the increased profitability for the
componenttext: Not directly, Ann. In fact, instead of just addressing Ag & Turf, let me look at it for the full company in relation to our full guidance, and just give you some of the numbers that are in implicit in our guidance. With the increased profitability for the company, incentive compensation is rising, and in the fourth quarter over last year, it would be about a $90 million expense. Again, very low levels of activity in the fourth quarter last year. Material, which has been either a neutral or a tailwind for us in the first three quarters of this year will be an expense in our projection, it's $75 million. R&D, we have a pretty significant jump. That's why Susan called out the fact that, year-to-date, we're up 6%. For the forecast, we're up 10%. That's about $55 million in the fourth quarter. That is a lot of money and that is very much impacted by IT4 as we're getting ready to enter into this very significant launch phase. And remember, we've got Final Tier 4 following on the heels in just, like, three years. Another factor is overhead absorption, and we estimate that at about $50 million. I shouldn't say overhead absorption, it's overhead expense. We have a very significant spend in R&D. Likewise, we have a very significant spend in capital expenditures ahead of us in the fourth quarter. And that is disruptive to the factory efficiency as you bring new machine tooling in, as you train operators. And so, we've provisioned for that in our outlook. And then the only other thing of note would be SA&G is a little higher as well.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then longer term, I know you wouldn't talk specifically about your outlook for your outlook for 2011. I know better than to ask directly. But could you talk a little bit about the overall global impact? With a negative impact in Russia because of the
componenttext: And then longer term, I know you wouldn't talk specifically about your outlook for your outlook for 2011. I know better than to ask directly. But could you talk a little bit about the overall global impact? With a negative impact in Russia because of the drought, what that might do to the protein sector in Europe and their input cost versus the positive impact it may have for U.S. farmers and South America farmers. How are you looking at putting all of these pieces together as you look in to 2011 and the health of global agriculture as we step forward?

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: You know, there's no question that the recent run-in in commodity prices driven by the events in the CIS, and even into Eastern Europe, certainly has supported the prospect for crop farmer incomes. You correctly note that livestock sector is a little more
componenttext: You know, there's no question that the recent run-in in commodity prices driven by the events in the CIS, and even into Eastern Europe, certainly has supported the prospect for crop farmer incomes. You correctly note that livestock sector is a little more concerned, obviously, with what's happened and especially just having come out of two years of very, very difficult financial situations. It is not as likely, therefore, you will have much crop, much herd expansion globally in the face of these rising feed cost. But overall, for the farm sector, it would appear to be very positive as you look into 2011. Some of the other factors though, Ann, that we're considering as we ourselves look into the future. Obviously, with the events of the last couple of weeks regarding the global economy, which seems to vary day by day. People are perhaps a little less certain than they were and that does raise a note of caution, especially a lot of talk about the U.S. economy, which would affect certainly our Construction Equipment business and our Turf & Utility. And frankly, even the small Ag sector because a lot of that is economically sensitive because it goes into homeowners and large property owners, et cetera. The other thing that you would want to think about is rising commodity costs affecting our materials as we go into 2011. I mentioned in the first question that I was answering of yours, that we have had a tailwind or neutral in the first three quarters of the year. That's worth about $250 million. If raw material costs just stay where they are today, obviously, that's something that would not be repeated. And the other thing I would just note is that we are and are going to be in the midst of this iT4 transition, we are very encouraged by the early results on it. We've got some good orders as Susan mentioned on the 8000 but it's very early. So you're really looking at a very small base. And so we'll see how that plays out as we look ahead. Jim, do you want to add anything?

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think that pretty much covers it.
componenttext: No, I think that pretty much covers it.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: How about pension? That's the one thing you didn't touch on going into 2011.
componenttext: How about pension? That's the one thing you didn't touch on going into 2011.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: As pension looks today, and of course, all things are never equal, we probably -- because interest rates are looking a little lower than they were at 31 October of 2009. We probably have a little bit of a headwind there as well, maybe $75 million. But obv
componenttext: As pension looks today, and of course, all things are never equal, we probably -- because interest rates are looking a little lower than they were at 31 October of 2009. We probably have a little bit of a headwind there as well, maybe $75 million. But obviously, we're a long way from 31 October, when we'll actually be setting the rates.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Stephen Volkmann. [Jefferies & Company]
componenttext: Our next question comes from Stephen Volkmann. [Jefferies & Company]

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering, Marie, you gave some forecast for cash receipts in the U.S. and net income in Latin America. Can you just frame for us how you think European farmers are going to be looking in 2011?
componenttext: I'm wondering, Marie, you gave some forecast for cash receipts in the U.S. and net income in Latin America. Can you just frame for us how you think European farmers are going to be looking in 2011?

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's early but people are pretty encouraged by the improvement in commodity prices. You're hearing some stories of customers having locked-in some good crop prices in selling their crops for good amounts of money. So we're encouraged. We still have used e
componenttext: It's early but people are pretty encouraged by the improvement in commodity prices. You're hearing some stories of customers having locked-in some good crop prices in selling their crops for good amounts of money. So we're encouraged. We still have used equipment to deal with, which is unknown exactly how that will impact our market as you move into 2011. We're starting to see a little bit of that equipment move. Again, that's very encouraging but there's a lot yet to be done, Steve.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: It sounds like you're saying farm income probably up in 2011 in Europe. I don't want to put words in your mouth but. . .
componenttext: It sounds like you're saying farm income probably up in 2011 in Europe. I don't want to put words in your mouth but. . .

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: You bet. That will play off against what happens ultimately with livestock prices and what happens to their feed costs. And livestock is about -- half the farmers in Europe have livestock. So it's significant to our customers.
componenttext: You bet. That will play off against what happens ultimately with livestock prices and what happens to their feed costs. And livestock is about -- half the farmers in Europe have livestock. So it's significant to our customers.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just a follow-up on the Construction business, obviously, we're seeing a nice recovery there in top line and in margins. How much of that is sort of dealer restocking? And do you think that -- where are we in that game, how much longer can that go?
componenttext: And just a follow-up on the Construction business, obviously, we're seeing a nice recovery there in top line and in margins. How much of that is sort of dealer restocking? And do you think that -- where are we in that game, how much longer can that go?

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: There's actually not very much dealer restocking taking place. Mostly what's happening, last year, when the dealer sold may be three units. He or she would replace one. Now it's more one for one replacement. So very little channel fill. Jim?
componenttext: There's actually not very much dealer restocking taking place. Mostly what's happening, last year, when the dealer sold may be three units. He or she would replace one. Now it's more one for one replacement. So very little channel fill. Jim?

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think Construction, if we look at sort of history, it has a very long runway in front of it because we are still at very depressed level relative to mid-cycle volumes. So I think we have a situation, we're running roughly 60% of mid-cycle volumes. So we
componenttext: I think Construction, if we look at sort of history, it has a very long runway in front of it because we are still at very depressed level relative to mid-cycle volumes. So I think we have a situation, we're running roughly 60% of mid-cycle volumes. So we think there's plenty of runway there.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jerry Revich. [Goldman Sachs]
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jerry Revich. [Goldman Sachs]

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Marie, can you say more about the drivers of your increased inventory receivables guidance for Ag & Turf? What proportion of the increase is related to Interim Tier 4, and which regions are driving the rest of the increase?
componenttext: Marie, can you say more about the drivers of your increased inventory receivables guidance for Ag & Turf? What proportion of the increase is related to Interim Tier 4, and which regions are driving the rest of the increase?

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, we're seeing strength in our Construction & Forestry business. So that is certainly a part of it. The other factor is just as we're getting closer to the 1st of January, we're starting to land on some of our plans. So we know a little
componenttext: Well, first of all, we're seeing strength in our Construction & Forestry business. So that is certainly a part of it. The other factor is just as we're getting closer to the 1st of January, we're starting to land on some of our plans. So we know a little bit more precisely how some of the transitions are going to occur. And also, very candidly, demand looking pretty good. I mean, again, it's very early. You're looking at small numbers. So I want to be very careful we put this in the appropriate context. But the demand for the products, the Early Order Programs seems to be going fairly well. Again, early. So that's encouraging. If you look at our tonnage increases for the full year and the fact, that our third quarter tonnage basically came in as projected, that tells you all of that increase is really happening in the fourth quarter. So it will take time for that production to actually translate into a retail sale because you've got to work it through the factory and then through the receivables. So we actually feel pretty good. Actually, Jim took a look at our receivables and inventories by historic standards, and they look really quite good. You want to. . .

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a big increase when you look at it, or perhaps could be viewed as a big increase when you look at it on a year-over-year basis. But, if you look back on historical context, really, this is receivables returning to levels that we last saw in '08.
componenttext: Yes, it's a big increase when you look at it, or perhaps could be viewed as a big increase when you look at it on a year-over-year basis. But, if you look back on historical context, really, this is receivables returning to levels that we last saw in '08. And inventory, actually, that ends at levels that are below the '08 level. So I think that hopefully provides some useful context when looking at that increase.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jim, good to see you buying back stock for the first time in a while this quarter. Can you update us on your framework for stock buyback? Are you going to be looking at it as a portion of your excess free cash flow or just update us on your broader framew
componenttext: Jim, good to see you buying back stock for the first time in a while this quarter. Can you update us on your framework for stock buyback? Are you going to be looking at it as a portion of your excess free cash flow or just update us on your broader framework?

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Unfortunately, I think we can't say a whole lot beyond the notion that we've had a very consistently articulated use of cash policy, and share repurchase is one of the things that we will look at from time to time based on our cash position, and we did so
componenttext: Unfortunately, I think we can't say a whole lot beyond the notion that we've had a very consistently articulated use of cash policy, and share repurchase is one of the things that we will look at from time to time based on our cash position, and we did so in the third quarter. I can't provide much more than that at this time.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Raso. [ISI]
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Raso. [ISI]

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: My question relates to the last comment about the production in the fourth quarter and it will take some time to translate into retail sales, and just trying to think about the margins in the Ag division. Two questions related to that then are, at what ti
componenttext: My question relates to the last comment about the production in the fourth quarter and it will take some time to translate into retail sales, and just trying to think about the margins in the Ag division. Two questions related to that then are, at what time in the order book can I no longer get pre-Interim Tier 4 tractor at a Waterloo? Are we already into the market knowing when we officially are out of production slots for pre-Interim Tier 4?

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Remember, we have a rolling product launch. So all that's been announced, so far would be the 8Rs. And if you would walk into your John Deere dealer today to order an 8R tractor, you will be ordering an Interim Tier 4 tractor.
componenttext: Remember, we have a rolling product launch. So all that's been announced, so far would be the 8Rs. And if you would walk into your John Deere dealer today to order an 8R tractor, you will be ordering an Interim Tier 4 tractor.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: But my question though is the broader Waterloo product line?
componenttext: But my question though is the broader Waterloo product line?

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have not made any further statements other than the 8R.
componenttext: We have not made any further statements other than the 8R.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Should it be terribly different than the 8R?
componenttext: Should it be terribly different than the 8R?

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: We haven't launched some of the -- I mean, so it's going to be a little while you could assume because we haven't said anything about some of the other products out of Waterloo.
componenttext: We haven't launched some of the -- I mean, so it's going to be a little while you could assume because we haven't said anything about some of the other products out of Waterloo.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm just trying to think through the profitability of Ag & Turf in the fourth quarter, and what's that implying about '11. Because even if I do add back some of those year-over-year impacts from short-term incentive comp up, material overhead absorption a
componenttext: I'm just trying to think through the profitability of Ag & Turf in the fourth quarter, and what's that implying about '11. Because even if I do add back some of those year-over-year impacts from short-term incentive comp up, material overhead absorption and so forth but also take the sales guidance for the year, it just seems like the implied incremental margins in the fourth quarter are interestingly low. So I'm just trying to think about the puts and takes. I guess, broader picture then for the whole company, the Construction margins for the fourth quarter, again, look around mid-single digits to get you the kind of lower single digit for the year. How are you thinking about the profitability of that division? You took down the '11 housing starts, but you're still implying some pretty healthy growth in housing starts '11 versus '10. Bigger picture, how are you thinking about the Construction division profitability off this recent kind of mid-single-digit level?

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: In the fourth quarter, specifically?
componenttext: In the fourth quarter, specifically?

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, you already can do the fourth quarter or you're implying about 6%.
componenttext: Well, you already can do the fourth quarter or you're implying about 6%.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: David, I'm sorry, I don't have any comments on 2011, if that's where you're going.
componenttext: David, I'm sorry, I don't have any comments on 2011, if that's where you're going.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Broader picture, how should I be thinking about the 5% to 6% we've been seeing third quarter, fourth quarter? How are you viewing that in the context of profitability of the division broadly?
componenttext: Broader picture, how should I be thinking about the 5% to 6% we've been seeing third quarter, fourth quarter? How are you viewing that in the context of profitability of the division broadly?

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, considering that they're at under 60% of what typical volume would be, we think they are working very hard and have demonstrated very good expense control and efficiency. As they move up into, what I will call, the sweet spot, which would be in the
componenttext: Well, considering that they're at under 60% of what typical volume would be, we think they are working very hard and have demonstrated very good expense control and efficiency. As they move up into, what I will call, the sweet spot, which would be in the 80% range and above that their opportunities will grow for profitability.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, David, too, when you look at that, you have some large percentage increases in sales, but if you look at the absolute dollar numbers and the incremental margin that, that would be expected to throw off. And then, you overlay what's going on with
componenttext: I think, David, too, when you look at that, you have some large percentage increases in sales, but if you look at the absolute dollar numbers and the incremental margin that, that would be expected to throw off. And then, you overlay what's going on with pension and OPEB, I think you get a long way to understanding the performance that, that division has demonstrated. And I think the other thing we would say, long term, the Construction division has demonstrated over the long term what they can do. And we would have every expectation that over time, they would return to where they've been at other points in the cycle.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: In a nutshell, that run you had from 2004 to 2007 in that division with solid double-digit margins, I'm just trying to think through how quickly do you feel, if we can get the revenue growth in '11. Is this structurally a double-digit margin business in p
componenttext: In a nutshell, that run you had from 2004 to 2007 in that division with solid double-digit margins, I'm just trying to think through how quickly do you feel, if we can get the revenue growth in '11. Is this structurally a double-digit margin business in pretty short order? Or is it how you're thinking about mix for '11 and a lot of other things that -- is that a little too aggressive a ramp and how you're seeing the recent run rate?

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, I can't comment on 2011. But I would very adamantly, very vehemently state that we see no reason at all why this business does not return to margins that it delivered in that period of time. And if you recall, their peak margin in that busin
componenttext: First of all, I can't comment on 2011. But I would very adamantly, very vehemently state that we see no reason at all why this business does not return to margins that it delivered in that period of time. And if you recall, their peak margin in that business was 14% and they actually are aspiring to a 14.5% margin. Like the Ag business in the near term, iT4 will affect them as well. They also have a staggered product launch that will be rolling out over the next couple of years, and so you'll have some impacts from that, but this business is on very solid footing.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Henry Kirn. [UBS]
componenttext: Our next question comes from Henry Kirn. [UBS]

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you chat a little bit about the impact of the pre-buy that your dealers may be reporting to you? At least on the equipment where you will have Tier 4 out early next year.
componenttext: Could you chat a little bit about the impact of the pre-buy that your dealers may be reporting to you? At least on the equipment where you will have Tier 4 out early next year.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: You know, as you look at what's happening, the very good level of cash receipts that we have in the marketplace, and it's accentuated further, frankly, by the recent run in commodity prices. You've got improved farm net income as expenses like fertilizer
componenttext: You know, as you look at what's happening, the very good level of cash receipts that we have in the marketplace, and it's accentuated further, frankly, by the recent run in commodity prices. You've got improved farm net income as expenses like fertilizer and various things have come in. You got historically low interest rates, very good value proposition in the market. We feel that the underlying economic fundamentals are in good support of the level of activity that we've seen. As we are moving closer to our launch date, there's no question that there is some pull ahead, but we believe the factors that I just mentioned really are the primary decision drivers. The other thing that you can, again, it's very small numbers, but it could provide some comfort, if you will, is the fact, that the Early Order positions are looking good on some of our products. And especially, perhaps more profoundly that the iT4 8R has a good order bank. Again, very early in the year and very early in the launch but it's actually been very encouraging.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And on the construction equipment side, philosophically, would you be willing to build some inventories at some point in front of expected rebound in demand from the rental guys and other contractors?
componenttext: And on the construction equipment side, philosophically, would you be willing to build some inventories at some point in front of expected rebound in demand from the rental guys and other contractors?

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our philosophy is to produce to retail demand. In Construction, actually slightly it's a different set of circumstances. As you are aware in Construction, in some areas you are required to use the latest technology. So you need to be -- if iT4 engines are
componenttext: Our philosophy is to produce to retail demand. In Construction, actually slightly it's a different set of circumstances. As you are aware in Construction, in some areas you are required to use the latest technology. So you need to be -- if iT4 engines are available, you need to be using that. Additionally, the bulk of the Construction product line, really is below 175 horsepower. So that's not going to be affected until 2012. And the other thing is, very frankly, we're at extremely low levels of activity and you don't see a lot of contractors with the financial confidence to go out and buy equipment that they may or may not use. The only indications where you may have a little bit of pre-buy ahead is in motor graders and some governmental segment but that's pretty small.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Meredith Taylor. [Barclays Capital]
componenttext: Your next question comes from Meredith Taylor. [Barclays Capital]

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm just going to go back to the Ag & Turf margin topic. I appreciate the fact that you've laid out a lot of the headwinds that you're looking at fourth quarter versus third quarter. Something that I'm hoping you can talk a little bit more about though is
componenttext: I'm just going to go back to the Ag & Turf margin topic. I appreciate the fact that you've laid out a lot of the headwinds that you're looking at fourth quarter versus third quarter. Something that I'm hoping you can talk a little bit more about though is the role that mix and productivity played in the third quarter for this business, and what your expectations are as we look ahead to the fourth quarter? I know you did note some overhead headwinds associated with Interim Tier 4. But if you could just talk about those two items in particular, third quarter versus fourth quarter, that would be helpful.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. In the third quarter, we did not make a comment specifically year-over-year on mix. Susan's comments about the two points overall for the year, really, relates to a typical year. So we're not looking at something that -- because remember, we h
componenttext: Absolutely. In the third quarter, we did not make a comment specifically year-over-year on mix. Susan's comments about the two points overall for the year, really, relates to a typical year. So we're not looking at something that -- because remember, we have a very good mix of large Ag in 2009 as well. So wouldn't really be a year-over-year factor. If you look at the third quarter and said just generally, how does that compare to a typical year? Then, yes, it would be about two points. If you look at absorption, last year in the third quarter, we dropped receivables inventory. I think it's like $1.7 billion. And this year, it was, I don't know, $300 million or $400 million or so. There is a favorable absorption impact in our third quarter results. And that is for the Ag & Turf division, it's about $90 million in their operating margin.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, as we roll forward to fourth quarter, I mean how should we think about mix there and then continued benefits from lean operational initiatives, et cetera?
componenttext: And then, as we roll forward to fourth quarter, I mean how should we think about mix there and then continued benefits from lean operational initiatives, et cetera?

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't have a comment per se on mix. I know some of the smaller stuff is coming up in the quarter, but I don't know what the actual impact is.
componenttext: I don't have a comment per se on mix. I know some of the smaller stuff is coming up in the quarter, but I don't know what the actual impact is.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And actually, in terms of the efficiency of the operation, as Marie said, we have a lot of transition going on and we do have some manufacturing inefficiencies built into the forecast for the fourth quarter, reflecting the very significant amount of chang
componenttext: And actually, in terms of the efficiency of the operation, as Marie said, we have a lot of transition going on and we do have some manufacturing inefficiencies built into the forecast for the fourth quarter, reflecting the very significant amount of change that's going to be occurring over this period of time, and some pretty significant capital items.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a quick follow-up on Lat Am. As I've look at the provided [ph] data over the last couple months. On the combine side of the market, I've noticed some volatility in terms of your wholesale numbers. Could you talk a little bit about what might be drivi
componenttext: Just a quick follow-up on Lat Am. As I've look at the provided [ph] data over the last couple months. On the combine side of the market, I've noticed some volatility in terms of your wholesale numbers. Could you talk a little bit about what might be driving this?

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. On the combine side, we converted to SAP on the 1st of May, and so we knew that we would not have shipments into the marketplace as we were making that transition. And so what you're really seeing is we're in a transitional period of -- I mean, those
componenttext: Yes. On the combine side, we converted to SAP on the 1st of May, and so we knew that we would not have shipments into the marketplace as we were making that transition. And so what you're really seeing is we're in a transitional period of -- I mean, those transition issues are behind us but you're seeing the results of just now restarting the shipping. So it was planned.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Eli Lustgarten. [Longbow Securities]
componenttext: Your next question comes from Eli Lustgarten. [Longbow Securities]

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's funny, we're all having trouble with the fourth quarter and may be put in the context that we haven't gotten the first three quarters anywhere close, anyway. So that's probably what having everybody -- you listed out $270 million worth of impact, but
componenttext: It's funny, we're all having trouble with the fourth quarter and may be put in the context that we haven't gotten the first three quarters anywhere close, anyway. So that's probably what having everybody -- you listed out $270 million worth of impact, but a large part of those things that you gave us, material R&D and that were known to be bigger in the fourth quarter. Anyway, we've known that. Are any of it much bigger than what we had expected, could you still can't get the margins almost cutting in half unless you put in either a huge impact from the transition products and the launches and what have you of putting into the guidance at this point. That's the trouble we're all having at this point. Is there something that's going on? Did you put more in the quarter on these costs than we expected? We knew they were all going up in the fourth quarter. R&D was going to be higher in the fourth quarter. We knew that from your guidance before, as well as material cost. It can't be -- something has to be driving the margin almost in half, which is what you're forecasting from the third quarter. And anything I can think of, you have more Ag & Turf, and the only other thing I can think of, is that you got a lot of inefficiency in from the new product launches and the models and all of that.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's kind of what we're trying to pick up with that $50 million overhead, if you will. The incentive comp probably is higher than maybe what you were expecting because of course, we've up our guidance for income in total, so that might also be at work h
componenttext: That's kind of what we're trying to pick up with that $50 million overhead, if you will. The incentive comp probably is higher than maybe what you were expecting because of course, we've up our guidance for income in total, so that might also be at work here. There's also a little bit of inventory build. That of course, that doesn't convert immediately into sales and so you don't get the marketing margin on that. There maybe a little bit of that as you guys are thinking about your modeling. Jim, do you have anything to add?

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Looking at 2011 production capability and pricing, prices have been announced and the new product has been relatively strong. So looking into next year, pricing going up from what you have announced and the anticipation that we're going to see more. How m
componenttext: Looking at 2011 production capability and pricing, prices have been announced and the new product has been relatively strong. So looking into next year, pricing going up from what you have announced and the anticipation that we're going to see more. How much more production capability will you have for a lot of these models? For the most part we're told that you sold out for this year in most of the big product line. How much more incremental production capacity we have next year? And is this pre-buy that we're talking about actually can be a rolling pre-buy in this market because Interim Tier 4 gets phased in over a couple of years and the price is clearly are going up materially as the product goes on.

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: It is true that we have a rolling launch. Again, we're not sure how much pre-buy there is occurring because the economic factors seem to support the level of activity that we are experiencing, and you've got good orders following into 2011. But you are co
componenttext: It is true that we have a rolling launch. Again, we're not sure how much pre-buy there is occurring because the economic factors seem to support the level of activity that we are experiencing, and you've got good orders following into 2011. But you are correct, that it will be a series of rolling launches both on the Ag & Construction side, if that helps. Waterloo had not put in all of the capacity that have been approved in 2008. They put in, I don't know if you recall, but it was about a 40% increase and they had about 25 points of the 40% in, and I expect that the remaining 15% will be available. I don't know if by the end of this year, but sometime in the not-too-distant future. So that will provide some additional assistance. Harvester had a 30% capacity increase that was in place, really, would have been fully available to us this year. And so that's there and ready to be used as required, and then there have been capacity at another facilities as well.

componenttext: I think Susan mentioned that your visibility into Brazil or Latin America financing right now is kind of through December, but the programs through December. Could you handicap or help us -- are you hearing anything about that getting extended or can you just tell us what your current thinking might be as far as next year?

headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: We believe that we will not know what the outcome of that will be until after the elections. In our planning, we're assuming that interest rates could rise from the current 5.5%, but that they would be unlikely to go all the way up to a market rate, which
componenttext: We believe that we will not know what the outcome of that will be until after the elections. In our planning, we're assuming that interest rates could rise from the current 5.5%, but that they would be unlikely to go all the way up to a market rate, which the rate before these current low-rate programs that come into play was 9.5%. And so, perhaps you've  got closer to 9.5%, but maybe not all the way there. So I don't have an exact number to give you. But I can tell you that in our own financial planning as we're looking into 2011, we're going to assume that the 5.5% does end at the end of December, and that the rate goes up a bit. Now the impact though for us will be delayed, actually for the industry, because the customer can make a contract by the end of the year having entered into a contract at the 5.5% that we can deliver. I'm not sure if it's 60 or 90 days still. So for us, are really effectively, our first and second quarters or at least a good chunk of the second quarter would be still effectively benefiting from that 5.5%.

componenttext: No. Really, the additional overhead that we are talking about really is just additional expense from rearranging production lines, the disruption that you have, you may have additional overtime because you have to bring people in to reset lines because you're adding a new piece of tooling or making some factory rearrangements. headline: Deere & Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again, we don't have a forecast for 2011. We will have a staggered series of launches, and I don't know how all of that will play out. We, ourselves, do not have our budget process done for 2011. So we'll see how that ultimately plays out. Maybe I could j
componenttext:
Again, we don't have a forecast for 2011. We will have a staggered series of launches, and I don't know how all of that will play out. We, ourselves, do not have our budget process done for 2011. So we'll see how that ultimately plays out. Maybe I could just end with a note that although there are a lot of things going on in the fourth quarter in terms of our guidance, I still want to point out that $375 million, which is our guidance would imply our second highest fourth quarter ever. And that's despite the start of these launches and some additional expenses, and the fact that you have weak markets in Europe and the former CIS and Construction & Forestry, although recovering is still, as we mentioned, still below 60% of typical. So we are very, very proud of the results we are delivering and we hope to deliver. 
And with that, thank you all for participating in today's call, and we will be available the rest of the day to answer your questions. Thank you.
