componenttext: Our next question comes from David Raso. [ISI]

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you give us some indication on how you see pricing for '11 for Ag & Turf?
componenttext: Can you give us some indication on how you see pricing for '11 for Ag & Turf?

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have price guidance for the full company of two points. Certainly, Ag & Turf is a strong participant in that guidance.
componenttext: We have price guidance for the full company of two points. Certainly, Ag & Turf is a strong participant in that guidance.

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: The reason I ask is doing that math, if you gave Ag just 3%, which I believe would be more than that, it implies Construction pricing down over 3% year-over-year.
componenttext: The reason I ask is doing that math, if you gave Ag just 3%, which I believe would be more than that, it implies Construction pricing down over 3% year-over-year.

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: You would be incorrect. Both divisions are looking for some positive price realization. And, David, that's as much as we can comment on that.
componenttext: You would be incorrect. Both divisions are looking for some positive price realization. And, David, that's as much as we can comment on that.

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: But can you just correct the math? If I do 3% on Ag revenues for '11 to get to 2% for the total company, construction...
componenttext: But can you just correct the math? If I do 3% on Ag revenues for '11 to get to 2% for the total company, construction...

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then the number must not be 3%.
componenttext: Then the number must not be 3%.

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: So then the question would be why would Ag pricing be less than 3%, given the 8000 R and even some of the price increases in the channel we hear for the rollover from the Tier 3 in front of the new Tier 4s?
componenttext: So then the question would be why would Ag pricing be less than 3%, given the 8000 R and even some of the price increases in the channel we hear for the rollover from the Tier 3 in front of the new Tier 4s?

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's a very good question, and do recall that when you take a price increase, that includes feature creep. When we give you our price realizations, we are stripping out anything that would involve higher horsepowers, new features, the IT4-compliant piec
componenttext: That's a very good question, and do recall that when you take a price increase, that includes feature creep. When we give you our price realizations, we are stripping out anything that would involve higher horsepowers, new features, the IT4-compliant piece. That is considered a feature and is put into volume. So when we give you our price numbers, we are looking strictly at trying to do an apples-to-apples, as-best-we-can comparison. So again, higher horsepower, IT4, all of that gets re-classed, if you will, into volume.

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I look at the 7% and 9%, then total Ag & Turf growth and strip out a pricing that's kind of apples-to-apples, not features, the unit growth is implied probably sub-5% or something like that.
componenttext: If I look at the 7% and 9%, then total Ag & Turf growth and strip out a pricing that's kind of apples-to-apples, not features, the unit growth is implied probably sub-5% or something like that.

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, our guidance in North America is for the industry to be flat. And that does reflect, as Susan talked about, the fact that, in large Ag, you are in a period of transition with some production limitations and some emissions credits management.
componenttext: Well, our guidance in North America is for the industry to be flat. And that does reflect, as Susan talked about, the fact that, in large Ag, you are in a period of transition with some production limitations and some emissions credits management.

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, that's not my question. The Ag & Turf receivables and inventory being down 7 50 for the year, a little bit is currency, I know, but still, underproducing retail. Can you pinpoint exactly where the underproduction of retail will be? I suspect, even t
componenttext: Well, that's not my question. The Ag & Turf receivables and inventory being down 7 50 for the year, a little bit is currency, I know, but still, underproducing retail. Can you pinpoint exactly where the underproduction of retail will be? I suspect, even though the combine new inventory is low, you might try to help out with some of the used sales by keeping new production low. But can you maybe highlight in particular where the underproduction will be versus retail and Ag?

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: It really has to do more with the work in process that we have in the factory in the fourth quarter of this year compared to what we think we will have and require in the fourth quarter of next year. That is not at all a prognostication on what the 2012 m
componenttext: It really has to do more with the work in process that we have in the factory in the fourth quarter of this year compared to what we think we will have and require in the fourth quarter of next year. That is not at all a prognostication on what the 2012 markets look like whatsoever. It really reflects the fact that this year, as we're getting ready for this very significant emissions change, we are in very high production levels on Tier 3 machines in the fourth quarter of this year as well as November and December. We do not expect to repeat that kind of production level. As you're aware, typically, it's pretty quiet, October, November and December here, relatively speaking, because were out of the use season. So what you're really seeing in that number, in Ag & Turf, is the fact that you don't have a lot of work in process at a time of the year when we are typically seasonally weak.

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Robert Wertheimer. [Morgan Stanley]
componenttext: Our next question comes from Robert Wertheimer. [Morgan Stanley]

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: My question is on Tier 4. Marie, I think you mentioned the incremental cost from the Tier 4 componentry, which makes sense. I would assume that part of the volume/pricing is trying to recoup some of the hundreds of millions or millions that you've spent o
componenttext: My question is on Tier 4. Marie, I think you mentioned the incremental cost from the Tier 4 componentry, which makes sense. I would assume that part of the volume/pricing is trying to recoup some of the hundreds of millions or millions that you've spent on R&D. So is it fair to assume that the margin impact, in other words the price volume is bigger than the cost, you just add the favorable margin trade in '11? And then, secondarily, the upped R&D expense, is that really getting ready for the models that launch in '12 and final testing and such? Or is that more the Tier 4 final and 2014 spending curve is starting?

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me start with the R&D. We have a significant launch in 2011. Some of the R&D is still for products that will be launched in 2011, certainly. There is very large wave again coming in 2012, so that's affecting the number. And then thirdly, we are hot an
componenttext: Let me start with the R&D. We have a significant launch in 2011. Some of the R&D is still for products that will be launched in 2011, certainly. There is very large wave again coming in 2012, so that's affecting the number. And then thirdly, we are hot and heavy into Final Tier 4 design work. Final Tier 4 starts in 2014, and if you are one of our design engineers, that is tomorrow. So there's a lot of work being done there. On the margin, we have some incremental investments and some new product deliveries. And the example would be like this large number of new product that we just took from Brazil -- I mean, we turned in Brazil. We are continuing to develop product for customers in many markets. Now going back to your IT4-cost question and price, we, over time, expect that we will fully recover our IT4 costs. But it doesn't happen all on day one. And so it is fair to say that in 2011, there will be some impact in our margins just on a product-cost basis, and it involves mix and timing and a whole variety of things. But over time, we will recover that.

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Andy Casey. [Wells Fargo]
componenttext: Our next question comes from Andy Casey. [Wells Fargo]

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the cash priority slide, can you help us understand how to define the term "excess" when you're talking about excess cash from an external viewpoint? Because kind of based on your cash flow outlook plus the current cash on the balance sheet for the equ
componenttext: On the cash priority slide, can you help us understand how to define the term "excess" when you're talking about excess cash from an external viewpoint? Because kind of based on your cash flow outlook plus the current cash on the balance sheet for the equipment side, it would be $5 billion plus at the end of '11.

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Depending on what we might do with repurchase and things like that, and then we've got a pretty significant amount of capital expenditures ahead of us as you are aware, et cetera. You need some amount of liquidity to run the business. And we've also talke
componenttext: Depending on what we might do with repurchase and things like that, and then we've got a pretty significant amount of capital expenditures ahead of us as you are aware, et cetera. You need some amount of liquidity to run the business. And we've also talked about the requirement of the rating agencies to have and is, frankly, it's just good business, to have a certain amount of our debt refunded. We deliberately included the chart on the debt maturity, which is on Slide #33, so that you would be aware of the fact that we had some pretty significant maturities coming particularly in 2012. And so, as you think about our year-end cash, we're going to have some portion of that cash on hand to cover what is a very significant maturity. Go ahead, Jim.

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we have chosen not to give sort of precise cash targets, because that analysis, of course, is very situational. And we look at some volatility indices that tell us what we're seeing in the underlying capital markets and the amount of cash will flex. H
componenttext: And we have chosen not to give sort of precise cash targets, because that analysis, of course, is very situational. And we look at some volatility indices that tell us what we're seeing in the underlying capital markets and the amount of cash will flex. Having said that, we have said that our forecast contemplates additional repurchases, which would certainly, I think, lead you to believe and appropriately so that the amount of cash that we have right now is, we think, more than we would need. And we intend, while not committing to any time line or amount, as we said, our forecast contemplates repurchases in the next fiscal year.

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then back to Henry's question, when you look at the performance that you had in October down in Brazil tractors, in terms of market share, were there any one-time benefits driving the share up for that particular month? Or should we expect low 20s is
componenttext: And then back to Henry's question, when you look at the performance that you had in October down in Brazil tractors, in terms of market share, were there any one-time benefits driving the share up for that particular month? Or should we expect low 20s is pretty sustainable in the short term?

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think market share you want to look at over a long period of time. We had some new products that had been launched earlier in the year coming into it. But I think you want to look at it over a long view. I can't promise that we'll repeat exactly what we
componenttext: I think market share you want to look at over a long period of time. We had some new products that had been launched earlier in the year coming into it. But I think you want to look at it over a long view. I can't promise that we'll repeat exactly what we did in October. But we're very encouraged by the market's reception of the products and the fact that we will have full availability as we move through 2011.

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ann Duignan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ann Duignan.

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's Greg Williams sitting in for Ann Duignan, JPMorgan. Just wanted to follow up on the transition costs going into fiscal '11. In R&D specifically, it looks like you're going for a 15% increase. That's about $1.2 billion a year and with the emissions st
componenttext: It's Greg Williams sitting in for Ann Duignan, JPMorgan. Just wanted to follow up on the transition costs going into fiscal '11. In R&D specifically, it looks like you're going for a 15% increase. That's about $1.2 billion a year and with the emissions standards and Stage III B 2012 and 2014, is the $1.2 billion a good run rate to use as we look beyond 2011?

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's very fair to say that our R&D spend will stay at very high levels. I think there's certainly -- that there could be some increase as you move forward. We don't have our crystal ball into what we'll be spending in '12 and '13 and '14 now, but
componenttext: I think it's very fair to say that our R&D spend will stay at very high levels. I think there's certainly -- that there could be some increase as you move forward. We don't have our crystal ball into what we'll be spending in '12 and '13 and '14 now, but I certainly wouldn't look for that number to abate in the near future.

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: And can you talk about the order board? I think, Marie or Susan, you mentioned they're on plan. I was hoping we can get some numbers behind that. And what time frame is that? Is that October or is that the fiscal quarter? How much of that would you expect
componenttext: And can you talk about the order board? I think, Marie or Susan, you mentioned they're on plan. I was hoping we can get some numbers behind that. And what time frame is that? Is that October or is that the fiscal quarter? How much of that would you expect was pre-buy activity? And what do you anticipate for pre-buy in the next month?

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, maybe the most significant item here is that on the 8Rs now, we indicated that we had 2,500 retail orders, which is a lot, for our machines that will be produced after the first of the year. So these are machines that are IT4 compliant. The
componenttext: Well, I think, maybe the most significant item here is that on the 8Rs now, we indicated that we had 2,500 retail orders, which is a lot, for our machines that will be produced after the first of the year. So these are machines that are IT4 compliant. They do carry a price tag, but they also have telematics and they have some additional features that we are getting very good reception from the market. And their fuel economy is basically neutral with the Tier 3, so people are very pleased with what they're hearing about our new product. And I think maybe that's the most significant point away from that. In terms of availability for 8000s, we're talking May. And for 9000s, we're talking March.

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Eli Lustgarten. [Longbow Securities]
componenttext: Our next question comes from Eli Lustgarten. [Longbow Securities]

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010

componenttext: Can I get a clarification? First, you said you're going to shut down construction for two weeks. When is that going to occur? And is there an implied cost of it? I mean, you told us you're going to have it. You just didn't tell us when.

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Midyear. So you're looking at an April, May time frame. And it would be included in that overhead that we were looking at of about $100 million. But again, the bulk of it is Ag. So I don't know, maybe, I'm guessing $10 million to $15 million here is const
componenttext: Midyear. So you're looking at an April, May time frame. And it would be included in that overhead that we were looking at of about $100 million. But again, the bulk of it is Ag. So I don't know, maybe, I'm guessing $10 million to $15 million here is construction.

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your guidance for the credit company is 360 up from 350 effectively. Can you give us what -- something's going on there. And the $20 million charge for the wind, I guess it pulled out of that stuff, is there any more charges coming in the next year in win
componenttext: Your guidance for the credit company is 360 up from 350 effectively. Can you give us what -- something's going on there. And the $20 million charge for the wind, I guess it pulled out of that stuff, is there any more charges coming in the next year in wind?

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. We don't contemplate anything at all for wind. I think one of the things that, I just would remind you, is in the second quarter, I think it was the second quarter of this year, we had some mark-to-market gains that we don't -- and of course, very har
componenttext: No. We don't contemplate anything at all for wind. I think one of the things that, I just would remind you, is in the second quarter, I think it was the second quarter of this year, we had some mark-to-market gains that we don't -- and of course, very hard to predict when that happens. And that was about $20 million after tax, and so we don't expect that that'll be repeated in 2011. And they also have a little bit of higher overhead SA&G, as they are working to support our international growth.

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: And a follow-up, I guess, we're all still struggling with this guidance, because if you strip out the healthcare charge, you still earn somewhere between $465 million closer $468 million, I guess, if you take out the wind charge also. And the implied guid
componenttext: And a follow-up, I guess, we're all still struggling with this guidance, because if you strip out the healthcare charge, you still earn somewhere between $465 million closer $468 million, I guess, if you take out the wind charge also. And the implied guidance of less than $5 just sort of doesn't fly with even $100 million going on. I mean, there's got to be something else that we're missing in costs or impact.

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, let me summarize those again then. Raw material costs are up $250 million. Mix is about a point of margin in A&T, and this is not a bad thing at all, because it means our Small Tractor business is starting to recover in Europe, for example. But that
componenttext: Well, let me summarize those again then. Raw material costs are up $250 million. Mix is about a point of margin in A&T, and this is not a bad thing at all, because it means our Small Tractor business is starting to recover in Europe, for example. But that's about it. 1% is about, in round numbers, $150 million. R&D, our guidance would tell you we're up about $150 million. SA&G, our guidance tells you there youre up about $140 million. Then we have the three items that I had alluded to earlier, which is the product cost of IT4, which is $135 million; overhead, $100 million; and absorption, $100 million. And that's where it goes.

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010

componenttext: And our last question comes from Stephen Volkmann. [Jefferies]

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to actually step back and look a little bit at the forecast, the industry forecast. And I'm interested that you raised your farm cash income expectations in North America and in South America. And certainly, the underlying crop fundamentals look
componenttext: I wanted to actually step back and look a little bit at the forecast, the industry forecast. And I'm interested that you raised your farm cash income expectations in North America and in South America. And certainly, the underlying crop fundamentals look pretty strong and yet we have kind of flattish forecast for those markets. And I'm wondering, do you think that we're just sort of saturated at this point and the cycle is kind of flattening out? Or is there some reason that you would expect farmers, despite these strong fundamentals, to have fairly flat purchases?

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, let's go back again. Our guidance for North America is affected by these very significant product transitions in IT4. That will have some impact on our ability to respond to customers' requirements. We will do our very best. But because of the need
componenttext: Well, let's go back again. Our guidance for North America is affected by these very significant product transitions in IT4. That will have some impact on our ability to respond to customers' requirements. We will do our very best. But because of the need to manage emissions credits, and as we've talked a lot already about the transitions and the fact that you have some capacity that's taken out effectively because of those transitions, we think that the markets will be affected in 2011 by that. So that's, maybe, in North America. In South America, again, the guidance specifically is looking at tractors and combines, which is certainly a very important part of the market. But it does not include what's happening in sugarcane and cotton. The other thing I want to point out is in the tractor market, as we look at it, we assume, because we don't know what will happen, that the very attractive 5% rate that the FINAME PSI has been offering will end and not be extended beyond the end of March because we simply don't know. And that's what's in our forecast. The other factors, there are two state government programs in Brazil that appear to be ending in December and not repeated. Those are targeted at small farms and lower horsepower equipment. So those two end. And we think that there's been a very significant number of tractor sold under MDA, which is the Mais Alimentos, which is the More Food program. That's the federal program in Brazil. Sales in the last two years each have represented about 30% of the industry. And we think that, based on the market dynamics, we think that we actually may see that segment slowing down, maybe off as much as a third next year. And so that's what's incorporated in our industry guidance. Again, that's the industry. When you look at Deere, we have all these new products. We've got a very exciting lineup ahead, and we're very enthused about our prospects into 2011.

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010

componenttext: We've talked, Jim, a little bit about the opportunity to maybe not have to pre-finance a full year of rollovers of maturities as the markets kind of normalized a little bit more. But I guess, the message you're giving us is that that's not going to happen in the next 12 months?

componenttext: No, and the agency that we're looking for is about 12 months of coverage today.

componenttext: We cover some of that with credit facilities as well, so we are not necessarily going to have 12 months worth of cash on the sheet. On the other hand, again, wed point to the very significant maturities that are ahead of us in 2012. And bear in mind, that's a lot of debt to...

headline: Deere & Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that metric is cash plus untapped credit facilities. So what we were looking at before was actually keeping cash 12 months, and we have backed off on that target.
componenttext: Yes, that metric is cash plus untapped credit facilities. So what we were looking at before was actually keeping cash 12 months, and we have backed off on that target.
